After the first few initial uprisings the public at large began taking an interest in the protests, and while at first the Burmese government begrudgingly allowed the monks to engage in peaceful gatherings, soon the violence escalated into what some considered an all-out war between the monks and the military junta, with the military actively invading and ransacking monasteries around the country. Foreign journalists were rounded up and imprisoned on sight, with a Japanese photojournalist named Kenji Nagai killed on September 27th, 2007, simply for being present at a street protest. While the official death toll rests at 13 killed, Colonel Hla Win, who defected from the army some days prior to the official report, is quoted as having said, “Many more people have been killed in recent days than you’ve heard about. The bodies can be counted in several thousand.”

This is nothing new. While these are some of the most recent examples of atrocities taking place in our world, a government’s desire to quash dissent and maintain complete rule over its citizenry has been around for as long as civilization itself. Early Roman emperors declared themselves chosen by the gods to have complete executive ruling over every aspect of their society. Japanese emperors are believed to actually be gods, sent to our world to lead their people to prosperity through the invention of Motorola cell phones and hara-kiri, and our current president, George W. Bush, has weekly conference calls with Ted Haggard, the leader of Stupid People Worldwide, a subsidiary group of the Republic Party.

Some of the most well known examples of these actions are such incidents as the 1989 June 4th protest at Tiananmen Square, where intellectuals, labor activists, and students all gathered to protest the authoritarian rule of the government. The death toll in that particular instance ranges wildly, with official reports from the Chinese government stating 200-300 dead to reports let out by the Chinese Red Cross, declaring between 2,000-3,000 dead.  Another is the Rwandan genocide of the 1990s, where Hutu militia groups, aided by the Rwandan government, began a systematic killing of all Tutsis, as well as political moderates, irrespective of their ethnic backgrounds. Hitler’s ‘Third Reich’, a period spanning several years and several countries where anyone of Jewish background was rounded up and killed, is another extreme example.

Duke Ellington’s legacy in jazz derives in large part from his longevity and, by extension, his creative abilities to shape his orchestra. Ellington’s presence on the piano is subtle in many of the compositions selected for this assignment, but as a composer Ellington excelled at creating rich and complex pieces that showcased the individual abilities of band members. Ellington crafted the framework in which a soloist could freely improvise, in addition to writing tightly orchestrated pieces and phrases that called on the particular style of band members to highlight musical ideas. In doing this, he also emphasized the tone of the orchestra more generally, creating coherent and original sounds to fit each piece. Ellington’s mastery of the individual players’ sound, as well as how they fit together in a growing ensemble, enabled him to write some of the most innovative and brilliant pieces in jazz history.
The Grove Music dictionary, in discussing Ellington’s sound and innovation, mentions Creole Love Call in reference to using voice “as a jazz instrument” throughout his career.  This is an early example of Ellington’s use of voice to add texture and color without the hindrance of lyrics. Creole Love Call also demonstrates Ellington’s ability to compliment the style of his soloists, something that is evident throughout his career. This slow, deliberate twelve bar blues piece contains six choruses, as follows:
Chorus 1: Call and response between voice and reeds, where the voice begins smooth and melodic, then transitions to a rougher sound towards the end.
Chorus 2: Muted trumpet solo that elaborates on the basic melody and emphasizes several extended blue notes.
Chorus 3: Sweeping clarinet solo in a high register, backed by a subtle syncopated piano phrase.
Chorus 4: Full band echoes the first chorus with a call and response by the brass and reed sections.
Chorus 5: The climactic chorus of the piece, as the reeds now begin the call and response in a high register, backed by syncopated stop time from the brass and rhythm sections.
Chorus 6: A return to the structure of the first chorus, with call and response between voice and reeds. In this chorus the voice takes on the sound of the “growl” technique, soloing as an instrument.
Tag: Brief tag featuring a vocal run and a dissonant novelty ending by a trombone.
Ellington’s use of voice to add a dimension of tone color to this piece is one example of a stylistic trait that permeates his work. 
In Hot and Bothered, recorded a year later, Ellington combines his skill at tight orchestration with his ear for tone color. A call and response phrase between “Bubber” Miley on muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing uses the vocal elements of Miley’s playing and instrumental aspects of Cox’s voice to create a rich and complementary sound. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) extends these ideas, as Ellington uses Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton, a mainstay in Ellington’s orchestra, to great effect in introducing the melody on muted trombone.

Why do organisms evolve in the manner that they do‭? ‬Are there restrictions or constraints that influence the direction of evolutionary change‭? ‬Although in‭ ‬1917‭ ‬D’Arcy Thompson stated that‭ “‬Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms‭” ‬the same can be said today. More recently,‭ ‬mathematical modeling has been applied to general aspects of mollusk skeletogenesis through both ontogeny and phylogeny‭ (‬e.g.,‭ ‬Raup and Stanley,‭ ‬1981‭)‬. Our study is exploring how mathematical modeling of ontogenetic and phylogenetic change in Prunum,‭ ‬in combination with experimental studies,‭ ‬can be used to elucidate the mechanisms involved in the direction and magnitude of evolutionary-developmental change. We used X-radiographic images of Prunum species to delineate quantitative parameters that could in turn be used to model hypothetical and actual skeletal morphologies. These parameters were entered into the software program CerioShell‭ (‬Stone,‭ ‬1995‭)‬. We modeled hypothetical shell morphologies that could be used to interpret the boundaries of possible morphological change in Prunum. These results are being combined with experimental and descriptive studies in order to better understand macroevolutionary events in this clade.

A shell can be thought of as a structure that is a tube that travels over time through‭ ‬360‭ ‬degrees of space.  These revolutions or turns of a coiled shell are called whorls,‭ ‬which are considered to spiral around an imaginary central axis.  This axis runs through the central column of the shell and is known as the columella. The speed at which the whorls enlarge can vary,‭ ‬and a continuous line separates each whorl and is referred to as a suture.  In most shells,‭ ‬the largest whorl of a shell is the last whorl‭ (‬body whorl‭)‬.  ‭ ‬The spire is considered to be all the whorls except the last. The apex is the tip of the spire and the opposite end is referred to as the base. The animal extends out of its shell through an opening called the aperture.

Shells can be viewed in apical,‭ ‬basal,‭ ‬apertural and abapertural views. ‭(‬The‭ "‬usual‭" ‬orientation of a shell is an apertural view,‭ ‬with the aperture toward the viewer and with the apex pointing up.‭)‬

A method for counting whorls is seen below.  First,‭ ‬the shell should be viewed from the apical view and then it should be determined where the first suture begins.  A line can be then drawn dividing the shell into two parts.  Whorls are counted from this line,‭ ‬and are estimated to a quarter of a whorl.

A shell can be viewed as a series of apertures that travel through time and space as the animal accretes‭ (‬i.e. builds‭) ‬its shell.  It is possible to trace the path of the aperture via coordinates of the center of each whorl’s aperture as well as the horizontal and vertical radius of the aperture.

This trajectory can be graphically and mathematically represented.  Once a mathematical formulation is made,‭ ‬it is then possible to vary parameters and modify the mollusk’s skeletogenesis.

The rate of neonatal and infant mortality in Indonesia remained rather static for the last ten years.  While the country is on track to meet many of the Millennium Development Goals, such as the water and sanitation targets, the rates of improvement for child and maternal health are woefully short of the improvements needed to meet their target goals by 2015.  The multiple reasons for these shortcomings will be discussed below, and point to a need to strengthen the health system rather than focus on programmatic interventions.
	Indonesia has made improvements in the number of births with a skilled health worker attending, with 72% of births now meeting this target.  That being said, this category still includes traditional workers, such as midwives, who cannot provide medical interventions should the pregnancy be complicated (hence the large percentage of maternal deaths caused by hemorrhage).  In other words,  the improvements made in this particular indicator are somewhat misleading and there is still much work to be done.  In addition, there has been a decline in the percentage of diarrheal cases in children under five years treated by a health professional.  While data on postnatal care is incomplete, it is clear that this area is also of concern, with low rates across the country.
	Cesarian-section rates are still lower than should be expected, around 4%.  The c-section rates additionally point to another concerning issue.  While the rate of c-section is 7% in urban settings, it is only 2% in rural.  This points to the problem of equity of coverage across the country.  Clearly access to healthcare services is focused around urban areas.  Another issue of access concerns vertical equity.  There is a 27% gap in service utilization between the poorest and richest quintiles.  Clearly the poor are finding it much more difficult to access healthcare services, likely due to out of pocket costs.
	In discussing next steps towards improving neonatal and maternal care indicators, the most basic question is how to most effectively address the lack of service.  Specifically, should Indonesia develop program-specific approaches or strengthen the overall health system without focusing on pre and post-pregnancy care for the mother and child.  There is no question that programmatic approaches to solve the problems outlined above are attractive.  Not only do “vertical approaches” that target one sector of improvements have much more targeted, manageable objectives, they also generally generate faster results.  There are some drawbacks to keep in mind, however.  One major drawback is that investing heavily in programming for one particular area of the health sector often means that funding for other areas suffers and human resources will flock towards working in that area that has more resources (the effect of international funding to HIV/AIDS and its effect on the family planning sector is one example).  In addition, running multiple parallel programs for one area results in duplication of services that are also uncoordinated between programs.  This leads to an increase in forms and paperwork for supplies and funding.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
He'd seen cultures clash before. Seen them rise up like specters in the night and tear at each other with teeth bared and claws extended. Seen how they could rend and destroy all hope of accord between men who might otherwise find common ground.

Culture aint no singular thing he thought. It dont rest easy in definitions or simple statements like Russians is stubborn or Japanese is accommodating. Such thoughts was poison to the mind of any man who aimed to deal with folk different from his own. Better to watch and wait. Better to see how the other's mind worked when confronted with the task at hand.

When a man finds himself in foreign territory he cant help but measure it against the familiar ground of home. Like comparing the taste of strange water to the well you grew up drinking from. But understanding comes slow like winter thaw. It means studying their histories their hatreds their fears. Means accepting what you find without trying to reshape it like some child's clay. This was especial true if you came to the table with a weaker hand.

Corporate culture was its own beast entirely. Each company like its own nation with borders drawn in dress codes and work hours and ways of speaking. Some demanded their workers wear suits like armor some let them come as they pleased. Some gave to charity like priests some hoarded wealth like misers. Even within the same company you might find difference enough to start a war depending on whether you was in the city or out in some suburban outpost.

Values was the bedrock of it all. The dark foundation everything else was built on. In some places a man would sooner die than shame his superior. In others nothing mattered but the deal itself raw and bleeding on the table. These things a negotiator had to know before he ever set foot in the room. But knowing the man across the table that was different. That was personal. Like knowing which snake might bite and which might slither past. Some things you had to learn face to face.

They'd spoken of God, these men of old. Fools and their hearts speaking empty words into the void. But there was Anselm and there was Aquinas and they'd walked different paths to the same dark water. No man could rightly judge between them without first accepting the God they sought, the one true God of scripture, terrible and ancient. To speak of other gods would be to speak of nothing at all.

They sat in their chambers, these holy men, writing by candlelight words that would echo through centuries. Anselm with his inward eye, searching the darkness of his own soul like a man in a cave feeling along the wet walls. He'd said that God lived in the understanding itself, that the very thought of such a being proved its existence. As if the mind could birth reality from its own red chambers. Faith was his lantern in that darkness.

But Aquinas walked a different road. He carried no lantern but the cold light of reason, following tracks in the dust of the world like a hunter. Five paths he'd marked out across the waste. Change. Causation. Contingency. Excellence. Harmony. Each one a trail leading to the same high ground. He believed a man could find God in the bones of the world itself, in the way things moved and changed, in the order that persisted in the chaos like a fingerprint in ash.

They were both right and both wrong, these ancient fathers. Each had found a piece of something larger than themselves but neither had grasped the whole. Like blind men describing an elephant, touching trunk or tusk or flank but never seeing the beast entire. Their words echoed still, carried on the wind like cinders, glowing briefly in the dark before going cold.

The truth was a thing that lived between their words, in the spaces they couldn't fill. It moved like smoke through their arguments, visible only at the corners of the eye, gone when you turned to look at it direct. Some truths could only be stalked, never captured. Some lights could only be seen in darkness.

Words lay like dead things on the page and a man could study them and know their meaning but knowing aint understanding. Fitzgerald knew this truth and in his book about the rich man Gatsby he put down words that carried more than their weight. He'd pair words that had no business being together and sometimes he'd take a thing like a color and make it speak volumes without saying nothing at all. Gold and green and white and gray and the red that sometimes showed pink in the dawn light. These colors spoke their piece in his story and told things about people and places that words alone could not tell.

White and gray spoke of sameness. The white carried itself higher, walked with its chin up while gray dragged its feet in the gutters and alleys but they was kin all the same. You could see it plain as day in how he wrote it. Daisy and that Jordan girl always wearing white like it was their birthright. Even Nick who told the tale wore white flannels to Gatsby's party and Tom had his white shirt on when he went to see that woman Myrtle. Catherine powdered white as milk. Only at Gatsby's did the colors run wild and free, bleeding their primary songs into the night.

The white kept coming like a tide. Down in them white canyons of New York where the buildings rose up like ancient monoliths. Gray names writ in Nick's book, fading already like they never was. Catherine's building just another slice in that great white cake of sameness that stretched on forever. Everything uniform and proper and dead inside.

He used these colors like a man uses tools. When he wanted to show something wasnt special he'd dress it in white or gray. Jordan and Daisy had their white girlhood, whatever that meant. The valley of ashes was gray as death itself, gray cars and gray land and gray people walking through it all like ghosts. That Italian child on the train, gray as yesterday's dreams. The old man selling dogs, gray as time itself.

Then he'd take them colors and paint Daisy with them. White dress, white car, everything about her white as bones bleached in the sun. It showed what she was. Just another piece in the game, something Gatsby wanted cause he thought it would make him whole. But it wouldn't. Nothing would. Her fur collar gray as morning fog, her dress white as a shroud before the storm broke between Tom and Gatsby. White and gray telling their story without saying a word.

The county lay stretched beneath the merciless sun, a patchwork of fields and orchards stitched together by old fences and dirt roads, the land itself a testament to what men could wrench from soil given water enough and time. Tomatoes grew blood-red in their rows and citrus hung like small suns in the groves. Leafy things. Green things. The peaches and lemons and berries all grown in this blessed warmth that knew no season. Lists of them written in ledgers and on computer screens but the truth of their existence was in the dirt and the calloused hands that worked it.

They called it organic now, this way of farming like the old ones did. Folk with money would pay more for such things, eggs and milk and vegetables grown without the poison that other farmers spread on their land like a curse. Waiting lists grew long as scripture. The farmers opened their gates sometimes, let city folk walk their paths and watch their birds and pretend at being close to the earth again.

The land itself lay near Potrero, one hundred and sixty acres of scrub and grass and oak trees pressed against the Cleveland Forest like a child against its mother. The government men had their plans for it, their lists of creatures they meant to save. Kangaroo rats and yellow-legged frogs and butterflies that danced on winds older than memory. The gnatcatcher too, that small gray prophet of better days.

Indians had walked this ground first. Then the cattlemen came with their herds and their axes, claiming squares of earth with paper and ink, turning the wild things to meat and timber. The ground remembered though. It remembered everything.

To farm such land right took more sweat than chemicals ever did. Weeds needed pulling, bugs needed picking, the soil itself needed feeding like a hungry child. But the old ways brought back the wild things. Birds returned. The ground grew rich again. A man could lose money doing it this way but there were programs, government men with clipboards who'd help if you let them tell you how to manage your own dirt.

They had a name for this piece of earth too. Called it the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion, wrote it down in their conservation plans like giving it a name would keep it safe. But the land didn't know its name. It knew only the sun and the rain and the patient turning of seasons, the slow pulse of life that moved through it like blood through veins, ancient and unstoppable as God.

Brothers carry a bond that runs deeper than blood and bone, deeper than memory itself. They know each other in ways no others can know them and see in each other's eyes the reflection of their own souls laid bare. In the darkest hours this bond shows its true nature whether that nature be merciful or cruel. These moments birth consequences that cannot be undone and leave marks that cannot be unseen. When brother looks upon brother he sees not what others might see but what truly dwells in the heart of both. Their actions speak louder than any words could and in those actions lie the truth of who they are.

In the story they call The Scarlet Ibis two brothers walked this path through the swamps and marshlands of their youth. The older brother carried within him a pride that burned like fire and the younger one named Doodle bore the weight of being less than what his brother had dreamed of. They moved through a world of cypress knees and spanish moss, through places where the mud was black as pitch and the water ran slow and dark. The older boy had wanted someone to race with through Old Woman Swamp, someone to climb the great pine behind the barn, someone to swim the dark waters to Horsehead Landing. But Doodle's heart was weak as wet paper and the doctors said he might not live at all.

The older brother's thoughts turned dark then. He would look at the infant lying there pale and small and think about pressing a pillow to that tiny face until the breathing stopped. But then one day the baby smiled at him and something in that smile reached down into whatever dark place such thoughts had come from and pulled them out by the roots. Even so the pride remained, burning away inside him like a coal that would not die. That pride would lead them both down paths that could not be unmade and into a darkness from which only one would return.

The brain. He'd seen it once, gray and wet and pulsing beneath the broken shell of a man's skull. Like some ancient machine built by forgotten hands. No computer this. No mere collection of wires and circuits but something more terrible in its complexity. Something godlike.

He thought about how it worked. How it took the world and made it real. Light and sound and touch coming in through the senses like thieves in the night, transformed into electricity and chemicals that coursed through neural pathways like rivers through a darkened landscape. Bottom-up they called it. Top-down. Words that meant nothing and everything.

The attention filter was there too, deciding what was worthy and what wasnt. Like some cosmic doorman at the gates of consciousness. You could hear your name spoken soft in a crowded room but the individual blades of grass beneath your feet might as well not exist. Unless they did. Unless they had to.

Memory was different. It came in pieces. Sensory memory that lasted mere seconds. Working memory that held on longer, electricity moving through loops of neurons like cars on an endless track. Then there was the long-term. Proteins twisted into shapes that held the past like fossils in stone. Sometimes they broke down. Sometimes they didnt.

The scientists had their models. Their networks of nodes and connections. Chair connected to table connected to wooden connected to nothing and everything all at once. But he knew better. The brain wasnt just connections and pathways. It was more than that. It was the sum of all things. The repository of all that was and all that would be.

He thought about the man's brain again. How it had looked there in the dim light. How it had ceased its endless calculations and gone still. How it had taken with it everything that man had ever known or loved or feared. Everything that man had ever been. In the end it was just meat. Just protein and fat gone cold in the night. But it had been something else once. Something more. Something terrible and beautiful and impossible to fully comprehend.

The money was gone. All of it. Like water through sand in some forsaken desert where no man walked and no bird flew. Two thousand and seven it was when the great wheels of commerce ground to their halt and the nation stood idle and mute before what was to come. Men without work and homes standing empty and the corporations that had stood like granite mountains laid low and broken in the dust.

They'd ask later how such things could be. How the world could turn so swift and terrible upon itself like some rabid beast. The answer lay in the hearts of men who wore fine suits and sat in tall buildings. Men who knew nothing of consequence or suffering. Who dealt in paper promises that held no weight. Who took the dreams of common folk and turned them into poison.

In the time before, during Clinton's reign, the seeds were planted. Like a cancer growing quiet and malevolent. The banks were told to give money to them that couldn't pay it back. Steven Holmes wrote the truth of it in the Times though none would heed his words. Fannie Mae, he said. Government men pushing them to lend to the poor while shareholders howled for blood in the form of profit. Holmes saw what was coming like a prophet in the wilderness. Saw the government would have to save them all just like they done before with the savings and loans. But no one listened. No one ever does.

They made new kinds of debt. Strange mutations of the old ways. Adjustable-rates and mortgage-backed papers and collateralized obligations. Words that meant nothing and everything. The whole nation betting on houses like drunk men at a crooked card table. When it fell it fell hard. The five great banks of investment holding four point one trillion in bad paper. Thirty percent of everything the nation made or did or had. Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch sold for pennies. Lehman Brothers torn apart like a carcass in the desert. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley brought to heel under government chains. Fannie and Freddie five trillion in debt and the government taking them over like some kind of failed state.

The nation watched it all happen like a man watching his house burn. Helpless. Mute. Knowing things would never be the same again.

The words lay dead on the page like bones bleached white in a merciless sun. They told nothing of truth. Nothing of life. Just dry facts scattered like ash across paper, meaningless as the wind that howls through empty doorways of abandoned homes.

Writer sits at her desk and knows. Knows deep in that place where knowing lives that the telling aint the showing and never was. Never could be. The stories that matter they dont come in lists of facts and figures. They come in blood and breath and heartbeat.

She remembers a man once. Air Force man working nights at a filling station out on Highway 9. Man with two wedding rings in a drawer somewhere and no young ones to speak of. Spent his Sundays with a pole in his hand watching the river flow past like time itself. Had dreams bigger than that station but smaller than the sky he used to fly in. Ate his eggs fancy style that morning like every morning, yolk running yellow as old memories.

But that aint the way to tell it. Story needs meat on its bones. Needs sinew and muscle to move it forward. Characters got to breathe and bleed and die right there on the page or they aint worth the ink that made them. Dialog has to cut like a knife or heal like a mother's touch. Every word's got to earn its place.

Exposition is the devil's own voice whispering sweet lies. Telling you to get it all out quick and dirty. Skip the heart of it. Skip the soul. But there aint no story without soul. Never was. Never will be. 

Truth is you got to let them live. Let them speak. Let them move through the world you made them leaving tracks deep enough to follow. Got to give them time to show who they are. What they want. What they fear in the dark of night when sleep wont come.

Anything less is just bones in the desert. Just dust in the wind.

He watched the screen flicker in the dark of morning, the news from Columbus casting shadows on the wall. First came word of Ashley, where a man named Hostettler had taken blade to wife. His mugshot stared back through the glass, eyes black as pitch, soul darker still. They gave it two minutes and moved on like wind through dead grass.

Then came the boy Travis Buyers, eighteen years gone from this world now by bullet in Sharon Woods. No killer found, though SWAT moved through the streets like wraiths. The story passed quick as summer rain, and he knew why. He'd seen it before, how the box treated dark flesh different from light, how some victims got remembered and others forgotten like dust in the wind.

The Med-Flight story came next. Small caliber round through metal skin, .22 they said. Somewhere out there in the vast dark a rifleman waited, five thousand dollars now the price of his name.

Weather rolled through like thunder itself. Rain coming, they said. Heat holding in the eighties like fever in a dying man. Quick as it came it went, bait to keep eyes fixed to the screen.

Then the UDF robbery on Clime Road. They lingered on the darkness of the man's skin like oil on water, six foot frame in a hooded shroud. One fifty on the scale. The words felt heavy with something unspoken, something that crawled beneath like insects under bark.

Last came the kingpin Rodriguez, Texas man moving green weight north like migration. Three hundred months they gave him instead of twenty-five years, numbers dancing strange in the telling. Hispanic, they said, though it mattered none to the time he'd serve in concrete and steel.

The news ended like all things must, leaving him alone with thoughts of how stories get told, how some words carry weight while others drift away like ash in the wind, forgotten before they hit ground.

He studied the numbers laid out before him like bones in the sand. ETF they called it. Exchange traded fund. A thing born of man's endless want to possess and control what could not be controlled. To track and measure and quantify the measureless march of commerce across the waste of time.

The boy looked at him. What is it Papa?

Its a way men tried to own pieces of the world without touching them. Like catching shadows in a box.

The numbers stretched across the page in their rigid formations. Each column a testament to man's futile attempt to impose order on chaos. The top holdings stood like sentinels. Ten of them. Accounting for 63.58 percent of all that was contained within. He ran his finger down the figures. Beta. Return. Standard deviation. Words that meant everything and nothing in the world that was.

They found that the return was higher in the ten than in the whole. 6.11 percent higher. A ghost of prosperity in a dead economy. The beta lower by point twelve. Numbers dancing their cold dance across the page like dead leaves in a winter wind.

He remembered the trading floors. The screens glowing blue in the darkness. Men in their dark suits watching the numbers rise and fall like the tide. All of it gone now. Ashes and dust.

To determine if the difference meant anything they would need to calculate the standard deviation. Another ritual. Another genuflection before the altar of statistical significance. The boy watched him work the figures.

Why do we need to know Papa?

Because knowing is all we have left.

But the numbers told no truth that could be trusted. They were ciphers in a dead language. Hieroglyphs on the wall of a tomb. The mathematics of a world that no longer existed.

They studied Figure 17 and there it was plain as death. The numbers fell off a cliff that third month, like something had died in them. Winter had come to New England like it always did, merciless and raw, and the bicycles stood abandoned and the footpaths emptied save for the wind that swept them clean. December it was, or what passed for December in these parts. The campus grew quiet. Students and teachers alike buried in their tasks like creatures before the storm. The commuter logs lay forgotten in desk drawers and computer screens, testimony to good intentions gone astray.

The holiday season descended like a shroud and with it came the great emptying. Halls echoed vacant and parking lots stretched bare under the cold sky. When they returned in January the numbers stayed low, as if something had broken that couldn't be fixed. February brought no relief. Perhaps it was the nature of such things, he thought. The fire burns bright at first then gutters out like a candle in wind.

They created what they called the Carpool Challenge Week in March. A desperate measure maybe but it worked after its fashion, breathing some life back into the dying thing. But they couldn't escape the truth of it - the academic calendar was a kind of death to momentum, cutting the legs out from under any forward motion they might build.

The deeper truth lay in the American soul itself. Cars were freedom. Independence. The open road stretching endless to the horizon. You could offer a man alternatives but you couldn't change what lay in his heart. They tried with their gifts - certificates for food and drink and comfort, for books and necessities. But it wasn't enough. He thought about bigger prizes - bicycles gleaming new under fluorescent lights, hybrid cars humming quiet as ghosts, electric vehicles that ran clean as winter air. If they'd done that, if they'd dangled those greater rewards like stars just out of reach, maybe the numbers wouldn't have fallen so far. Maybe the logs would have kept coming in through those dark winter months, testament to human persistence in the face of easier paths. But they hadn't done that. They'd kept to their modest offerings and watched the numbers fall like leaves in autumn, scattered by winds they couldn't control.

I sat there in the dim light of the archive room watching them old Edison films one by one. Fifteen of them from 1895 to 1901. Magic pictures they called them then. Trick films. Moving shadows that danced and disappeared on the wall like spirits conjured up from some ancient projector grinding in the dark.

The films was mostly bound to stages like theater shows. Everything frontal and far off like you was watching through a window into another world. No movement of the camera. No getting close to the faces. Just figures moving side to side in their fixed space like marionettes on invisible strings. That's how it was back then. That's how they learned it from the vaudeville shows and magic acts that came before.

In Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel the figures moved like ghosts across the frame. Right to left. Left to right. Never coming closer never moving away. The camera watched unmoved like some dead-eyed god. That's how they all was. Every one of them trick films bound by rules older than the pictures themselves.

They shot everything from far off or middle distance. Never close. Never intimate. Like watching life through the wrong end of a telescope. The audience got what the stage gave them and nothing more. No faces. No details. Just the whole scene laid out before them like some moving tableau.

Most of them films was just one shot. One minute or less of magic. Of vanishing. Of things appearing and disappearing like fever dreams. But they wasn't really one shot at all. They was pieces stitched together to fool the eye. Like that film of Mary Queen of Scots. If you looked close enough you could see where they'd cut it. Where they'd sewn the pieces together to make her head come off. But folks didn't look close back then. They just watched and believed in the magic of it all.

The films was like windows into another time. A time when pictures moved for the first time and people gathered in the dark to watch shadows dance on walls. When magic was still possible and tricks could still fool the eye. When the world was younger and simpler and full of wonder.

The Gothic tale aint nothing but old made new again, least thats what them scholars say. Like some ancient thing dredged up from the black waters of time and set to dry in the modern sun. Some called it empty, others praised its terrible beauty like a storm rolling across the plains at night. When Walpole wrote that first one, The Castle of Otranto, he took what was dead and breathed life into it, made something that weren't quite alive nor dead but walked the earth nonetheless.

He built it from old timber and new nails, using them theatrical ways of the past mixed with what folk called the natural telling of things. Like some mad carpenter fashioning a house from bones of different beasts. Gothic it was called, though that word had been passed round so much it had worn smooth of meaning, like an old coin rubbed blank between too many fingers. Folk looked down on it, called it primitive against their fine modern sensibilities. But that marriage of old theatre-ways and the new intimate telling, that's what gave it power. Power that lingered like smoke in still air, making it both dead and alive to them that read it years later, centuries later.

Chivalry stood at the heart of it all, like some old oak in a dead forest. That medieval notion of what makes a proper knight, it got twisted and changed in Walpole's hands but never quite lost its shape. These Gothic writers, they saw something missing in their time, some honor or bravery that had leaked out of the world like water from a cracked jug. They looked back at them knights of old with longing, making heroes of shadows. Walpole himself was neck-deep in the political muck of his day, watching good men turn bad and true things turn false. Maybe he thought something pure had been lost, something that them knights of old had carried in their iron hearts.

You can see it clear as day in how he writes Frederic, painting him with all them old colors of chivalry. A prince who'd known suffering, marked by tragedy, thought to have fallen to the blades of infidels. He made him larger than life, like some statue carved too big for human proportion, excess piled on excess till it near toppled over with the weight of its own telling.

The chain moves like a great serpent through the land, from raw earth to the hands of them that would possess its yield. Oliver he was called, the man who gave it name back in eightytwo. A consultant. He reckoned it needed planning and watching and steering like some great beast that might otherwise run wild and wreck all in its path.

Six parts it had, like the chambers of some industrial heart. Production and supply and inventory and location and the moving of things and the knowing of things. These the overseers used to feed the hunger of them that would buy.

Production stood first among them, like some dark foundation stone. It asked its questions. When. Why. Where. How. The overseers they had to know what the people wanted and they watched the marketplace like seers reading entrails, trying to divine what numbers to set down in their ledgers. Which things to make and how many and where to make them. They chose their grounds careful, like a man picking a place to make his stand.

I worked once in them great stores, Walmart and Target both. Everything laid out just so, like a ritual. How to wear the clothes they gave you, how to take in the goods when they came. Everything written down in books like scripture.

The supply was the second thing. Strategic they called it. Core capabilities. Words that meant nothing and everything. Sometimes they'd split the work between different places, different hands. Sometimes theyd send it out beyond their walls to other makers, other shops. Velocity they called it. The hunger for speed and quality both, and the getting of it cheap. The eternal struggle between what things cost and what they're worth.

Each overseer watching his own piece of the great mechanism, all of them connected like the bones in a spine. If one failed the whole thing could come apart. The shelves would empty. The people would hunger. And in the end it was all about the hunger, wasnt it? The endless hunger of a world that could never be filled.

Dark and godless they were, them Victorian tales. All gilt and finery draped over the bones of the aristocracy like clothes on a hanged man. But there were two that walked a different path. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights. Stories that carried mystery in their bowels like some biblical beast, strange and terrible tales that gave flesh to their characters in ways no parlor story ever could.

The boy Oliver dreamt dark dreams. Walked with killers in his sleep while his mind burned with fever and pain. Sikes and Crackit moving through the dark like specters, their words hanging in the air like smoke. Then gunfire split the night and screams rose up like birds scattered from a field. Lights swimming in the dark. Pain everywhere and nowhere. Some hand he couldn't see dragging him through the void.

Time itself bent and broke in these stories. Day becoming night becoming day, all of it meaningless. The boy had no control over any of it, no more than a leaf has control over the wind that carries it. The old jew Fagin had worked his devil's magic well, breaking the boy's spirit like you'd break a wild horse. Even with death reaching for him with both hands the boy couldn't fight. Wouldn't fight. Just let the darkness take him like it was his due.

In these moments the truth showed its face. Not in the fancy drawing rooms or behind lace curtains but in the fever dreams of a dying boy. In the spaces between heartbeats when the world goes quiet and a soul can hear its own echo.

Two years past I worked with the young ones after their schooling had ended for the day. Teaching them what little I knew. English mostly and some reading. One of them teachers come to me about a boy. Adrian was his name. Third or fourth grade, couldn't say which now. Said he couldn't read right. Watched him struggle with the letters like they was foreign things. Some he knew true as sunrise but others may as well have been marks in the dust. Brown skin that boy had and spoke English clean as any of them but something wasnt right.

Days went by. We worked at it. Then come a day when his mother appeared in that tired classroom while the others was gone on some venture. She stood there and no English passed her lips. Only Spanish words I barely understood with what little I knew of that tongue. Standing there I saw it clear as bones in the desert. The boy could read fine enough. Just didnt know our letters proper. Whether that knowing helped him none I cant say.

I tell this tale cause of what it means. Here in California we got children who cant read the words we give them. Even them that speak it good as anyone. Adrian he just needed teaching in our letters and sounds but there's many who need more than that. Aint no simple answer neither. Two-language learning. Throwing them in with the rest. Special teachers. None of these alone will do it.

What works is all of it together like a wall of stones. Each piece holding the other. Teaching two tongues aint just for them that speak Spanish first. Studies show it makes all of them sharper. Some folks fear it. Say it wastes what little we got. They're wrong as wrong can be. We dont need every teacher speaking two tongues but we need some that do. Like guideposts in the dark. Showing the way.

They tell you when youre small that theres something bigger than you are. Something you cant wrap your mind around no matter how hard you try. Some folk take their children to wooden buildings with crosses nailed to the walls and some to temples made of stone and some just look inside themselves for whatever truth they think might be there. Most just take what their mothers and fathers gave them like a hand me down coat. Others spit on the very notion that anything could be bigger than their own small world. A man might choose one way of believing then cast it off like snakeskin for another. Whatever path we take we're all searching for that thing that makes us whole. Looking for that light in the black that'll guide us home.

Me and my father sat on the porch that day. Rain coming down hard on the tin roof overhead. Both of us with cigarettes. The gutters running full and drowning out the flowers below. Cardinal, he said when I asked him what bird he liked best. He stared out into the rain like a man trying to remember something he'd lost. His clothes hung on him like a scarecrow's. His hair thin and patchy where it used to be thick. He wouldn't look at me and I couldn't speak of what was coming because speaking makes a thing real. I moved closer and hugged him and we both watched the rain fall in the failing light of that June evening.

He died in December. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The doctors with their medicines and their machines bought him a few more months of suffering and I never could reckon the worth of that. What sort of God would do such a thing. I laid in the dark those nights. No prayers passed my lips. If there was a God he'd stopped listening to me long ago.

I wouldn't watch him die. Couldn't. You cant watch the life that made you while it leaves this world. I wanted to keep him how he lived not how he died. I knew him better than any of them did. Better than his own kin. And I knew he wouldn't want his only child watching while death took him. So I curled up in my bed and waited three days for word.

Nobody even called.

The man called Taylor of Caroline walked the fields of his land and knew the worth of soil and seed and sovereignty. In those early days of the Republic he stood testament to the old ways, though he was no stranger to the halls of power where men spoke of governance and law. But it was the earth that shaped him and gave weight to his words about freedom and the rights of men to work their own ground.

He saw in this new country something that had never been before. A land unbound by the old ghosts of tradition. A place where men might govern themselves if they had the courage for it. He knew that rights were like bones in the body of liberty. Break one and the whole corpus fails. These things must remain beyond the reach of any government lest all be lost.

The world of nature he knew was red of tooth and claw where the strong preyed upon the weak but civilization could not abide such ways. He saw that government must account for the darkness in men's hearts while preserving what light remained. Good and evil moved through his thoughts like wind through winter wheat. As government is exercised by man all its virtues and vices must be human, he wrote, knowing the truth of it in his bones.

He believed good principles were those that protected what a man owned and worked for, that improved the tilling of soil, that stood against the moneyed interests who would make all men slaves to coin and paper. Self-interest drove all things but turned poisonous when it led men to feed upon their brothers.

Like others who stood for the old Republic he held to the Constitution's words with iron certainty. The federal power must be bound and limited lest it grow fat and tyrannous on the people's bread. Yet he knew too that words alone were dangerous things without the spirit that gave them life. The Declaration was his true charter, for it spoke of sovereign states and not one nation bound in chains of power. He saw these truths as clear as he saw the furrows in his fields, and spoke them with the same certainty that seeds would sprout in spring.

He stood there watching. The porcelain bowl white and cold beneath the fluorescent lights that hummed like distant wasps. His mind moved through the scene like water over stone, taking nothing with it, leaving nothing behind. Just the watching.

He remembered a book. Some woman had told him about it once, an artist woman who spoke of the right side of the brain and how to see what was real in the world. How to frame it. How to make it small enough to understand. But there wasnt any frame for this. No way to make it smaller or more comprehensible. It was what it was.

The brown mass lay there in the bottom of the bowl like some primitive creature pulled up from the depths of the earth. Like something that had no business in the world of men. Picasso had his blues and Monet his greens but this was his color now. Brown. The color of endings. The color of what gets left behind.

His hand found the lever and pulled. Water swirled and moved like spirits in the bowl but the thing remained. Unmoved. Uncaring. He flushed again and watched the water rise and fall. The fluorescent lights buzzed. The green tie at his throat felt like a noose.

He stood with his feet set wide on the tiles. The mop beside him like some useless weapon. The paper rolled off the roll like bandages for some wound that wouldnt heal. Layer after layer wrapped around his hand until it was something else entirely. Not a hand anymore but a tool. A thing for doing what needed doing.

When he reached into the bowl his arm moved slow and careful like a man reaching into the mouth of something that might wake up and bite. The water was cold. Everything was cold. The world was cold and this was what was left of it. This was what they paid him for. This was what men did.

They die behind the wheel. Young ones. Not yet grown. The statistics tell their tale in cold numbers and charts but the dead care nothing for such things. The National Institute speaks of brains not ready, not formed, like wet clay not yet hardened in the kiln of years. But there is more to it than that. More darkness in the hearts of the young.

He watched them on the roads. Inexperienced. Raw. Their vehicles rolling and tumbling like dead leaves in an autumn wind. Speed demons chasing something they could not name. The asphalt calling to them like some dark siren song.

They travel in packs, these young ones. Like wolves. Studies done in the southern lands of California showed the truth of it. The more of them together, the more bones scattered on the roadside. States tried to cage them with paper laws. Provisional licenses. Time restrictions. But laws are just words on paper and the young have always held such things in contempt.

The psychologist Zuckerman knew. Even at eighteen the blood runs hot and wild. They seek the thrill like addicts seeking the needle. The rush of speed and danger coursing through their veins like some precious poison. He had seen it in their eyes. That hunger. That need.

By the year 2010 they would come in waves. The children of the boom times reaching driving age like some great migration. Millions of them. The roads would run red with their passing.

The solution lay in waiting. Let them learn in classrooms and simulators but keep them from the wheel until eighteen summers have passed. Let them practice under watchful eyes. Six hours behind the wheel. Fifty hours with an adult present. Like an apprenticeship to survival.

The law would need to be universal. Coast to coast. Border to border. One rule for all the young. It was not a new idea. Others had spoken it before. But sometimes old medicine is the strongest medicine. Sometimes the old ways are the only ways.

He thought of all the young ones yet to die. Their faces unknown but their fates already written in the cold equations of probability. Perhaps there was still time to save them. Perhaps. But time was like water in a cracked vessel. Running out. Always running out.

The boy watched him scrawl upon the yellowed paper with a worn pencil stub. Words about the broken ones, them that cant hear right in their heads. Not deaf mind you but somethin worse. Like their brains was wrapped in cotton. Like God himself had reached down and pulled some wires loose just to see what might happen.

He wrote about them that studied it first. Italian doctors with names like prayers. Bocca. Calearo. Cassinari. Back in fifty-four when the world was younger and less cruel. They'd sit with children broken in ways you couldn't see and they'd make their tests and write their findings in thick leather books now turned to ash somewhere.

The afflicted ones they'd tested couldn't place sounds in the world like normal folk. Couldn't tell which way a voice came from or pick one voice from many. Like trying to catch fish in muddy water with your bare hands. Some couldn't hear the difference tween a question and a threat, couldn't make sense of the simplest things said to them. Their brains betrayed them. Simple as that.

They got doctors now that'll test for it. Audiologists they call em. White coats and clipboards and machines that measure the echoes in your head. They'll sit you down and whisper numbers in your ears and make you repeat em back. They'll ask you questions about what you hear and don't hear and write it all down in their precise hand like scribes recording the words of prophets. But there aint no one test that'll tell you for certain. No machine that can look inside and point to the broken part and say here, here's your trouble.
