The cause remains a mystery, like most terrible things in this world.

He set down the pencil and studied what he'd written. Words marching across the page like soldiers heading to war. Each one carrying its own weight of meaning. Each one a testament to the ways we break and the ways we try to mend what's broken.

The boy sat on the couch and his eyes were wild with fear like some trapped animal. He knew what was coming. They all did. The social work it called to me like a dark bell tolling in the night. Not then maybe but soon enough. The darkness in mens souls and the things they visit upon their children. I had seen it before. Would see it again.

The degree in psychology hanging on the wall like some talisman against the evil that men do. But it wasnt enough. Never was. The police they stood in the yard that day watching. Just watching. The parents in their hollow righteousness spouting words like manipulative and simple disputes but their eyes betrayed them. Evil has a look to it. You see it enough times you dont forget.

I knew then what I had to become. A worker in the darkness. Someone to stand between the innocent and the void. The values burned in me like a flame. Service. Justice. Ethics. Words that mean nothing until they mean everything. Until they're all that stands between a child and the darkness that would swallow them whole.

I had always been different. Hair the color of nuclear sunsets. Metal in my flesh like some tribal marking. A warrior for the different ones. The lost ones. The gay and the straight and all the spaces between. Fighting the old battles against hate and ignorance. These were my people. The ones society wanted to make invisible.

The social work it calls to you like a siren song. Like something ancient and true. You either hear it or you dont. And if you hear it you cant unhear it. It becomes the thing that drives you. The thing that wakes you in the night. Because out there in the darkness children are crying and someone has to answer. Someone has to stand in the doorway between innocence and evil and say no further. This far and no further.

And that's what I aim to do. To stand in that doorway until they plant me in the ground. Because evil never sleeps and the innocent need their warriors. Their protectors. Their workers in the social dark.

The dark shapes of sleep and wakefulness move through us like spirits in the night. They come unbidden and go as they please and we are powerless against their ministrations. In the laboratory they keep mice in small metal cages and study how sleep comes to them or doesnt. The scientists speak of things called neurons firing in the hypothalamus, orexin coursing through the brain like some biblical flood. They speak of receptors called GABAB as if naming old testament prophets. These receptors they say govern the coming of sleep and its going.

The mice they study are not unlike us in their need for rest. Their small hearts beating in the dark of their cages while the white-coated priests of science watch and make their marks in leather-bound books. They speak of something called baclofen that makes the mice sleep longer and deeper. As if sleep itself could be caught and measured and weighed like grain.

There are those among us who cannot sleep. Who lie awake in the vast darkness while the world turns beneath them. Their genes carry some ancient curse passed down through blood and bone from father to son and mother to daughter. The absence of proper receptors in their brains leaving them to wander the midnight hours like restless ghosts. 

The scientists say their research with the mice can tell us about ourselves. About why some can sleep and others cannot. About how this failure of sleep moves through families like some dark inheritance. How it destroys lives as surely as any plague - taking first the ability to work, then to think, then finally the will to go on living in a world without rest.

They keep their mice in metal cages and study them and make their marks in books but the truth of sleep remains mysterious as death. The neurons fire or they dont. The receptors work or they fail. And in the end we are all at the mercy of forces we barely understand, forces as old as the darkness itself.

Been here at University Park going on three years now. Time moves like water through a sieve. Dark mornings walking east from Stuart Hall where they'd put me that first year, far out on the edge of things where the stadium stands like some colosseum against the gray sky. Twenty-five minutes by foot to Willard if the weather held. Weather rarely held. Some old timer told me bout how it was before. Said East Halls stood alone out there like some outpost, nothin but empty land between. Not anymore. Sports fields now. New buildings risen up like concrete monuments. The Creamery. Health Services. Apartment blocks crowding round like mourners at a wake. Campus growing like some living thing, reaching out across the valley floor. Distance growing with it.

Bicycle's the answer. Simple as that. But answers aint worth nothing without action behind em. Need riders. Need paths. Need the whole damn thing built right.

Friend of mine took up riding again after years without. Said he couldn't reckon why he'd ever quit. Said bikes was the only true way. Bowl of oatmeal'll take you thirty miles if you're willing. I live off campus now, far as any dorm. Bought myself a bike. Best thing I ever done. Thomas building's my daily destination. Twenty-five minutes walking. Five minutes riding if you pump hard enough. Pollock Road runs straight as an arrow but it aint friendly. Like some river of humanity flowing both ways, everyone in their own world, everyone moving like the world's about to end.

Walking's good for the soul maybe but time aint kind. Without the bike I'd be burning daylight. Thirty minutes extra each way to Thomas. Two and a half hours gone each week like smoke in the wind. More when you count everything else. Time's precious out here. Time's all we got.

He sat there in the dim light reading the words again. Words about a world that never was but might yet be. The book lay heavy in his hands like some ancient tome speaking prophecies of darkness. Brave New World they called it. Weren't nothing brave about it though.

The world in them pages was a cold one. Clinical. Everything measured out in droppers and test tubes, life itself parsed and portioned like medicine. Community they called it but it weren't no community he'd ever known. Just people moving like machines, thinking thoughts put there by others. The Controller watching over it all like some dark god in his high tower.

Marx had seen it coming maybe. That old prophet of the working man speaking through time about false consciousness and hegemony. Big words for simple truths. The truth that men could be made to love their chains if you gilded them proper. In that brave new world they'd done just that, made folk happy to be slaves. Deltas and Gammas and all manner of greek-lettered souls moving through their days like sleepwalkers, dreaming dreams fed to them in the dark while they slept.

Weren't no real love in that world. No passion neither. Just bodies moving against bodies, mechanical-like. Men speaking of women like they was talking about the weather, clinical words about pneumatic this and pneumatic that. Women too, talking about their couplings like they was discussing what they had for breakfast. All of it hollow. Empty as a dead man's eyes.

He thought about them social classes, stacked up like cord wood. Each one content in their place cause they'd been told to be content. Consuming and obeying and never questioning why. The upper classes watching it all, knowing maybe but not caring. All of them caught in the same machine, just different gears turning different ways.

The whole thing speaking to something deeper. Something about how men lose their souls when machines and money become their gods. How technology and capitalism together could strip a man down to nothing but wants and needs, all manufactured proper-like by them that knew how. A warning maybe, written in ink but speaking in blood.

He closed the book. Outside the wind moved through dead trees, whispering secrets to no one at all.

The class on Islam came to me four winters past at CBC, dark thoughts weighing on minds like storm clouds. They spoke of hostility in the faith, voices rising and falling like wind through dead grass. The question hangs heavier now than it did then, like a noose waiting for its neck.

I watched how the papers and screens changed their telling after the towers fell. First came the rage, hot and blind as wildfire. Then something else. A kind of forced kindness, stretched thin as spiderweb. Strange days these are when a man called Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his veins, could reach for the highest seat in the land.

The Prophet's tale troubles me. The words dont match the deeds, like footprints leading two ways. They say he was gentle but history speaks otherwise. I seen how he took the tribes, one after another, blade first then faith following. Yet here in these pages they paint him soft as lamplight, a martyr walking through sand and time, people following him like lost sheep finding water.

They wrote him performing works that mirror the Christ's own doing. Took meat and milk and made it more, feeding forty men till they could eat no more. These words feel hollow, like bones picked clean. They wanted him holy, needed him holy, but the truth is a different beast altogether. It's a theft of sacred things, taking Christ's glory and draping it over their own prophet like a borrowed cloak.

The stories come third-hand or worse, passed mouth to mouth like desert gossip. Someone heard from someone who heard from another, on and on till truth gets lost in the telling. They meant it for proof but it reads like smoke, nothing solid to grasp.

What eats at me most is how they made him gentle when gentleness wasnt in him. They wrote of wisdom and humility but the blood tells different. I wonder if those who bow toward Mecca know the true shape of the man they follow, or if they too are lost in the stories, believing what they need to believe.

The truth of the Christ and what he spoke in his time was lost quick as breath in winter, scattered to winds that carried new thoughts across the land after his passing. Like tracks in ash swept clean. Looking back across the years you could see how the teaching got further and further from where it started, like a man walking away from his home till he cant see it no more behind him. These days theres a knowing in people. A different kind of knowing that wasnt there before. The old ones still cling to what their fathers told them but they grow fewer, like trees in a burned forest.

The Christians that remain will come to see what was lost. Theyll hunger for it like men dying of thirst. Theyll want to peel back the layers of words men put over the words of God like paint over paint until they find what was first written there. Maybe it'll take a hundred years. Maybe more. But it'll come sure as winter follows fall. They'll strip it down piece by piece, like taking apart an old house board by board till nothing stands but the foundation that Jesus himself laid down. When this thing sweeps through the old countries itll carry people with it like leaves in a river. The church will still stand but itll be different. Simpler. More like it was.

Where once there were a thousand different ways to worship therell be just one. Like streams joining to make a river. The differences between men will wash away like footprints in rain. History's got a way of turning back on itself, like a snake eating its own tail. Time was when Romans killed Christians in the streets but then Rome itself knelt down before the cross. This country once kept men in chains and now those same men's sons sit in high places. The wheel keeps turning.

They'll read his words different too. Not like reading a map but like reading poetry. Looking for the truth behind the words instead of in them. To understand how we got here you got to go back. Back before there was any such thing as Christian. Back when there was only the old religion of the Jews. They believed in one God and holy books and divine revelation. But even then they were split five ways - Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots and the common folk who followed none of these. Each claiming they knew the truth of things.

They was greedy folk them owners and managers and they knew it deep in their guts but they didnt care none. The factories rose up like great black mountains against the sky and the smoke poured forth like rivers of death flowing to the ends of the earth. Aint no man ever looked down from them heights and saw anything worth saving below. The workers was just numbers to them. Numbers on paper written in ink black as their hearts.

The place they called Packingtown was a hellhole of suffering where men and women worked themselves to bone and marrow for scraps while the bosses grew fat on their misery. Loyalty was a word that held no meaning there. Everything had its price and a man's worth was measured in dollars and cents. The owners would sooner see a worker dead than spend a penny more than they had to. That was the truth of it plain and cold as winter.

The smoke rolled thick and black across the sky and the stench of death and rot hung in the air like a curse. Animal waste ran in rivers through the streets mixing with the blood and the filth. But them that owned the place they just watched from their offices high above counting their money while below the people suffered and died.

Wasnt no laws to protect them workers back then. No safety regulations nor nothing to keep the owners from working them till they dropped dead on the killing floors. The unions that come along they was just as bad. Vultures picking at the bones of them that was already half dead from the work. Most of them workers was foreigners desperate for any kind of work and the owners knew it. Used it against them like a whip.

They was slaves in all but name. Living on the edge of starvation day after day dependent on the mercy of men who had none to give. The morality of such a place was like everything else there corrupted and diseased. The whole system was rotten through and through like meat left too long in the sun. And there wasnt no escape from it neither. Not for them that was caught in its grip.

The darkness lay over Dreamland like a shroud, black and ancient as time itself. In those pages Poe had writ the word Thulé, scratched it there twice as though marking the borders of some forsaken realm. The word itself carried echoes of Virgil's voice across the centuries, speaking of lands beyond the edge of knowing, north of Britain where the Greeks had drawn their maps to end in mist and legend.

But there was something else. Something closer. The German writers had gotten into Poe's blood like a fever. Their words moved through him like dark water through deep caves.

There was Goethe. His Faust stood like a monument, carved in two great pieces across the years - first in 1808 and again in 1832 when death finally took him. Within those pages lay "The King of Thulé" like a dark jewel. It told of a king whose queen had passed beyond the veil, leaving him nothing but a goblet and his grief. He drank deep from both until neither could sustain him. When the end came he gave away his kingdom like a man shrugging off a heavy coat, keeping only that cup, that last token of love. Then he walked out onto the cliffs above the sea, black water moving below. The goblet caught the light one final time before he cast it into the depths. Then he closed his eyes and followed it into darkness.

The shade of that tale fell across Poe's "Dream-Land" like an evening shadow. He wrote of Thule twice, bookending his verses with that ancient word as though to mark the borders of that desolate realm. His speaker wandered landscapes stripped of color, haunted by the ghosts of dead companions, moving through a world as empty as the one Goethe's king had left behind.

The connection ran deeper than chance. Poe knew Goethe's work - how could he not? It moved through the literary world like blood through veins. When they spoke of Tennyson, Poe would nod, knowing the threads that bound them all together across the dark waters of influence and time. The reproductions of Goethe's work spread like ripples in still water, touching everything. Even Grattan had shaped Faust anew in 1842, barely a year before Poe set down "The Pit and the Pendulum" with its own whispered mention of ultima Thule.

They'd tell stories later about that day at D&D Markets. About the applesauce that lay there like some pale viscous blood upon the floor and how Martin sat in his office eating while fate worked its slow arithmetic in the aisles beyond. The spill had come at five. Wayne had seen it first. Told Martin who sat there behind his desk with his dinner laid out before him like some pagan offering to darker gods. Didn't have time for customer complaints he'd said. His voice flat and dead as winter.

Fifteen minutes passed and Haddigan came. She too bore witness to the creeping danger in aisle four but Martin would not be moved. He sat immobile as stone while time crept past like a thief in the night. Half past five Palmer came. She never saw what took her feet from under her. Never saw the applesauce gleaming dull and treacherous in the fluorescent light. Her back broke bad and she fell into darkness deeper than any night.

The law spoke of malice and oppression and fraud. Spoke of despicable acts committed with willful disregard. Six souls had fallen in those aisles that year alone. Six victims to negligence and indifference cold as the tile floor itself. The judges knew such things. Had seen them written in blood and broken bones across the years. Taylor's case spoke of dangerous consequences known but not heeded. Of willful failure to act when action might have saved.

Martin knew. He knew and still he sat. Still he ate while danger waited patient as a rattler in the aisles. The law would not look kindly on such things. Would not shield him from the punishment such calculated indifference called forth. Palmer's claim would stand. The courts would hear her tale of woe and pain. Of a manager who chose his dinner over duty. Who let peril stalk his store while he supped in safety.

The law was clear as morning. Clear as the applesauce that lay there waiting. Punitive damages would come like judgment day. No summary dismissal would save them now. The facts lay bare as bones and twice as damning. They would pay in coin and conscience both.

The wanting had come early. Like a shadow that follows but never catches up. Started when she was fourteen and lingered still at seventeen, a ghost of need that wouldnt rest. Not a thing she needed no. A someone. But the boys that came didnt matter none. They'd circle like crows round a dying thing, awkward in their courtship, but she felt nothing for them. Nothing at all. She'd lay awake studying the ceiling, questioning what darkness lived inside her that made her this way. Years passed like that. No answers came.

The house was quiet mostly. Her folks were peaceful folk who rarely raised their voices, save when their daughter's wild spirit crashed against their stillness like waves on stone. She was their opposite, full of life and light that drew others to her like moths to flame. Good hearted too. Kind.

But this day wasnt quiet. No. This day carried something else. She wandered room to room searching for something she couldn't name when her mother's scream cut through the silence like broken glass. Kitchen. She ran. Found her mother laid out on the tile floor, face twisted in pain, breath coming short and sharp.

Mama what's wrong? She knelt beside her mother who could barely speak through the hurt. Hospital, her mother managed. Just take me there.

The girl gathered her mother up, thankful for the strength in her arms from all them classes she'd taken. Carried her to the car and laid her in the back like something precious and broken. Drove fast through streets gone colorless with worry.

The hospital reeked of death and cleaning fluid but she noticed none of it. Just carried her mother through them sliding doors calling for help until white-coated figures appeared like ghosts from the fluorescent haze. They took her mother away on a wheeled bed and left the girl alone with her fear.

Later they told her. Her mother had been reaching for some old vase, balanced on a stepstool like a bird on a wire. Then gravity remembered her and brought her down hard to the unforgiving earth.

They watched them dying year by year. Hearts giving out like old clockwork, blood vessels clogged and useless. The nurses knew. They'd seen it before and they'd see it again. Seventy four thousand of them watching and waiting and marking their charts with what they ate and what they didn't. Mediterranean style they called it. Plants and fish and oils pressed from ancient trees. No meat to speak of. Like them old desert people used to eat before the world went wrong.

The women they studied weren't sick yet. Not with the sugar disease nor the heart troubles. Thirty eight to sixty three years old they was. Every few years they'd write down what passed their lips. Everything catalogued like a church inventory. Two decades of eating and dying. Some quit the study but most stayed on. Faithful as converts to some old religion.

The doctors checked every death. Every seized-up heart, every blood vessel burst in the brain. They'd look at papers and records and death certificates like archaeological artifacts. Sometimes there weren't no records to speak of. They called them probable cases and counted them anyway. Seventeen percent of the strokes. Twenty four percent of the heart attacks that didn't kill.

They kept track of everything. Weight and smoking and pills they took. Whether their monthly blood still came or if it had stopped. Whether they moved their bodies or just sat still. Like bookkeepers tallying up the accounts of lives lived and lost.

They used numbers to wash away the noise. Averaged everything together like mixing paint. Tried to account for things that might lead them astray. Age and smoking and all them other habits that kill.

After twenty years they had their answer written in blood and death. Two thousand heart attacks. Near eighteen hundred strokes. Over a thousand dead from their hearts or their heads giving out. But them that ate like them old Mediterranean people, they lived longer. Twenty nine percent longer than them that didn't. Like some old testament prophecy come true in hospital corridors and nursing stations. Eat of these foods and live. Eat of the others and die.

The sign said Hitler lives in Burma and the girl held it there above her head in the gray morning light. The cardboard bent and weathered like something pulled from an ancient tomb. Standing alone on that corner like a prophet of old. The country they called Burma once and Myanmar now lay far across waters dark and deep where men in uniforms ruled with iron and blood since before most could remember. The military junta they called them. Words that meant nothing to the dead.

In the year two thousand and seven the monks rose up. Orange robed like flames against the concrete and steel of the cities. The Saffron Revolution they named it but revolutions aint got much to do with spices and this one was no different. At first the government let them march. Let them gather. Then the violence came as it always does. Ancient monasteries ransacked and burning. Journalists rounded up or shot dead in the streets. One Japanese man named Nagai caught it there on the concrete while his camera kept rolling til the end.

They said thirteen dead but a colonel who fled told different stories. Bodies stacked like cordwood in the thousands. The government denied it as governments do. Ancient as time itself this need to rule. To stamp out the light wherever it shows. Roman emperors who called themselves gods. Japanese kings descended from heaven itself. Our own president taking counsel from prophets and madmen every seventh day.

In China they gunned down students in the streets of Tiananmen. The numbers changed depending on who did the counting but the dead stayed dead all the same. In Rwanda the Hutus killed their Tutsi neighbors with machetes and clubs til the streets ran red. And before all that there was Hitler. The girl with the sign knew. Knew how these things went. How they always went. Evil didnt die. It just moved on down the road looking for new places to root.

The old jazzman's shadow stretched long across them decades like some dark thing that wouldnt die. Piano keys worn smooth by time and the endless nights. He didnt play much but when he did it was like rainwater falling soft on tin. His real power lay in knowing the souls of them that played for him. Each one carrying their own particular sound like a birthmark or a scar. He wrote the music but it wasnt just notes on paper. It was blood and breath.

The book men talk about something called Creole Love Call like it was just another piece of music but it wasnt. Voice rising up out of nowhere like some lost spirit crying in the dark. No words. No words needed. Just pure sound floating above them reeds like smoke. Blues wrapped around blues wrapped around blues six times over.

First the voice comes pure as morning then turns rough like somebody dragged it through gravel. Then that trumpet crying through the mute like it knows something about suffering. Clarinet floating high and lonesome while the piano whispers underneath. Then the whole band takes up the cry, brass and reeds calling back and forth like wolves in the night. Fifth time through everything rises up fierce and wild, them reeds screaming high while brass and rhythm punch holes in the dark below. Last time voice comes back growling like some creature that aint human no more. At the end just a run of notes and that trombone laughing bitter and wrong.

Year later he done Hot and Bothered. Miley on trumpet and Cox singing sounds that wasnt words, just pure music. Like they was having some kind of conversation that normal folks couldnt understand. Then that piece about swing, Nanton making that trombone talk like it had a human tongue. Playing sounds that wasnt never meant to come from brass and metal.

That was his gift. Taking human sounds and making them mechanical. Taking machine sounds and making them human. Mixing them all up till you couldnt tell which was which no more. Like some kind of dark alchemy. Like he knew something about music that wasnt in no books nowhere.

He sat there studying the shells. Ancient things. Spiraling through time and space like some cosmic dance frozen in calcium. The old man Thompson had said it back in 1917 that no man could speak the language of these forms in numbers and equations and even now a hundred years hence they still could not. Not really.

The shells lay before him on the wooden table. Prunum specimens collected from waters he'd never see. Each one a record of life and death and the slow accretion of being. Mathematical models could tell you something of their growing but not everything. Never everything. They'd X-rayed them, fed numbers into machines called CerioShell that spat out predictions of what could be and what couldn't. As if the world needed telling.

The shell was a house built by its tenant, spiral upon spiral like the chambers of some infinite heart. Whorls, they called them. Each one marking time like rings in a tree, each one pressed against an axis running through the center that men had named columella though God knows what the creature called it. If it called it anything at all. The last chamber always the largest, like the final breath of a dying thing. They had names for every part. Apex and base and aperture. Words to cage the mystery but never quite holding it.

You could turn them this way and that. View them from above or below or straight on but they kept their secrets. Counting the whorls was like counting the years of the dead. Draw a line and start where the first suture begins, marking quarter turns like the phases of some calcium moon.

The path of growth could be tracked. Numbers assigned to the spacing and the width and the height as if that could capture the essence of the thing. As if mathematics could explain the why of it all. But the numbers were just shadows on the cave wall, telling nothing of the thing itself. Of what drove it to build in curves and spirals, to leave these empty houses scattered on the shores of time.

He touched one shell with a finger. Smooth and cold. Wondering what compulsion had driven its maker through the dark waters, adding layer upon layer in the blind faith that this was what it must do. This was its purpose. This was its being. Mathematical models could predict the possible but never the necessary. Never the why of it all.

He studied the numbers before him, cold figures that spoke of death in the far reaches of those islands. Ten years and nothing changed. Children dying same as they always had. Mothers too. The government men had their goals written in fine ink on clean paper but the truth was darker, more brutal than their neat columns could tell.

In the cities now you might find someone who knew the way of birth. Seventy-two out of hundred they said. But these weren't doctors with their clean hands and sharp tools. Just women who'd seen enough blood to know its ways. When the bleeding started they had nothing but old ways and prayers. He'd seen it. The dark blood flowing like river water in the night.

The children still died of the flux, their small bodies wracked with it. Less help now than before. The numbers told that truth plain enough. In the towns where the roads were paved you might find a doctor to cut the baby free. Seven in hundred. But in the places where the dirt was still dirt and men lived close to the bone it was two. Just two. The math was simple as a knife.

Rich folk got their care. Poor folk died. Twenty-seven percent difference they called it. He called it blood money. Called it the price of being born wrong.

They talked about programs now. Special ways to fix special problems. But he knew better. Knew you couldn't patch a rotting house board by board. The whole thing needed tearing down, building new from foundation up. They'd tried it before with the plague that took men's blood. Threw money at it like water on a fire. But the fire just moved elsewhere, burned through the family planning houses instead. That's how money worked. Like water finding the low ground.

The papers piled up on desks. Forms in triplicate. Programs layered on programs like old paint, each one hiding the rot beneath. But the children still died. The mothers still bled. And the numbers stayed cold as stones.

The music they called Popular had grown and spread like some dark vine across the century past, spawning genres uncountable, each one birthing more in its wake. They had names for them all. Rap and rock and country and jazz and folk but these were just words men had given to something that defied naming. And from these came others still, subspecies breeding in the dark corners of sound until they became something else entirely.

Among these bastard children was one they called Heavy Metal. It came forth some forty years ago and grew like something feral, something that refused to be contained. It spoke in tongues of darkness and carried within it emotions raw and terrible as birth. Men saw in it something malleable, something that could be shaped and reformed endless times, and so they did.

Now the thing has grown so vast and strange that none can say what it truly is anymore. It feeds on other sounds, other genres, consuming them and making them its own. To understand this thing you must go back to its beginning, to the dark soil from which it grew. For this aint no mere category of sound. This is something that moves through the world like a fever through the blood.

The darkness lies at its core like a black seed. Everything about it demands more. More thunder in the bass, more volume to shatter eardrums, more violence in its execution. The players themselves became technicians of sound, masters of their craft in ways the old musicians never were. And always there were the drugs, flowing through the veins of the seventies like poison, making men create sounds that weren't of this earth. They used these chemicals like shamans use their herbs, to touch something beyond the veil of reality.

It carried within it something visceral, something that hadn't existed in the popular sounds that came before. It reached back to the dark romanticism of another age, pulling forth themes of death and decay and loss. Even the Beatles, those prophets of love and light, found themselves drawn to its power. They wrote Helter Skelter like men possessed, trying to outdo the Stones in their descent into the maelstrom. That song stands now like a marker, a sign pointing toward the darkness to come.

In the time before the dreamers took to their canvases with their wild visions, there was Rousseau. He who held his brushes like ancient tools of some forgotten ceremony. The Dream they called it, this thing he made in 1910, this fever vision of woman and jungle and night. She lay there midst the dark fronds and violet blooms, pale as bone china in the spectral light, while all round her the jungle breathed and watched with golden eyes.

He'd come to painting late, had Rousseau. No schooling in the arts save what the world had writ upon his heart. Born to a tinsmith in Laval where the gray streets wound down to the river and the sounds of hammering rang out across the morning fog. For forty years he collected tolls, counted coins, watched faces pass. They called him douanier though that wasnt right. Gabelou was what he was. A counter of small coins. A keeper of minor gates.

Grief walked with him like a shadow. Eight children born dead or dying. His wife Clémence taken too, leaving him with only Julia, this one daughter like a single candle burning in a vast and darkened room. And so he turned to paint and canvas like a man turns to prayer, seeking something that might fill the emptiness.

He worked in silence while around him others rose to fame. Matisse with his wild colors burning holes in canvas. But Rousseau, he painted slow and careful like a man trying to remember something seen in dreams. Some said he wanted only to be accepted, to make the kind of paintings that would open doors. But in his heart he knew. The jungle waited. The dreams came calling. And he answered them with brush and paint, making worlds that never were but somehow always had been.

The critics laughed. The galleries turned away. But still he painted on, each stroke a defiance, each canvas a door opened onto somewhere else. Somewhere in the dark beyond the firelight where the dreams still walked upright and spoke in tongues of flame and shadow.

He sat there thinking on them that came before, them great minds what spoke of truth and beauty being bound together like twins in the womb. Something in that notion rang true deep down in the marrow of things. Old Keats had wrote it plain as day in his poem bout that old urn, said beauty and truth was one and the same and that was all any man needed knowing in this world. Most things a man learns comes from books or hard living but these things, the knowing of what's right and what's beautiful, they come to a man different. Like they was already there waiting to be found.

He remembered studying them paintings in museums, folk talking bout foreground and background and such, trying to pin down why something like that Mona Lisa woman spoke to the soul. But words failed. Always failed. People'd look at some painting or read some book that moved em and they'd say there was just something about it before they started in with their fancy talk. Truth was you couldn't never capture it complete. That O'Connor woman knew it, said some things could only be told in stories cause regular words wouldn't do.

The boy looked up at him. What are you thinking about Papa?

About truth and beauty son. About how they're like ghosts you can feel but cant never quite catch hold of.

Like God?

Maybe so. Maybe just so.

He thought on how both goodness and beauty worked on a man's soul in ways that couldn't be spoke proper. Like they was both reaching down from some higher place, touching something deep inside that was beyond telling. Them books he'd read talked about noumenal things, things that could be felt but not explained. That's what it was like. The knowing of right from wrong and the knowing of beauty, they was kin somehow. Connected in that deep place where words don't go.

Especially in them stories folk wrote. McKean had it right when he said stories was different from other arts cause they carried the weight of living in em. Values and such. The choosing between right and wrong. Just like real life only distilled down somehow. Pure. Like truth and beauty was just different words for the same thing after all.

The land stretches vast and cold from the teeth of the alps down to where the Baltic meets the shore at Kiel, a place where men speak in low voices and the wind carries salt. This is Germany. The same blood runs through the veins of those who dwell by the Rhine at Köln as those who wake in Dresden where the Elbe cuts through stone like an ancient knife. The people carry something in them older than memory. Something that came before.

They called it Germania once. The old ones did. The name itself is lost to time like footprints in ash, disputed by learned men who speak in whispers through dusty tomes. Tacitus, dead these thousand years, wrote of the Tungrians who crossed the Rhine with blood in their eyes and war in their hearts. Caesar too spoke of them. Called them Germanus in his writings of the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls like dogs but could not tame those who dwelt beyond the river. He took the word from the Gauls themselves, though what it meant none now living can say. Some claim it spoke of neighbors. Others say it named the spears they carried, dark instruments of death called ger, or maybe it came from garim, an old Irish word for shouting, for these were a people who made the very air tremble with their voices.

Tacitus wrote more. In 98 he put down words about these people, claiming they were pure as winter snow, unmixed with the blood of others. Who would come here, he asked, to this wild country with its bitter sky and darker ways? Who indeed would leave warm southern lands for this place unless it was already branded on their soul?

The Romans would not. They sent their legions north for plunder and glory but always they returned south like birds in autumn, back to their marble halls and heated baths. The Germanic tribes lived on the edge of this empire of stone and law, trading what the land gave them and sometimes their own blood, serving in the ranks of armies not their own. They were there in the middle of that first century, watching, waiting, their destiny as yet unwritten in the book of days.

The play stretches out before us like some vast tapestry of deception, each thread woven through with lies that must someday unravel or else consume the weaver whole. They'd called it Twelfth Night though it mightve been called anything. A story of masks and faces beneath masks and the terrible price of wearing either too long.

The girl Viola comes to strange shores. Comes walking out of the sea like some halfdrowned thing. She takes a mans clothes and a mans name as if such things could be borrowed like coins. Protection she called it. As if cloth and leather could ward off the worlds malice. But the disguise that saves can also damn and she found herself cut off from the women who mightve been sisters to her. Cast adrift in a wilderness of her own making.

The noble Olivia sees this false man Cesario and something burns in her that maybe shouldnt burn. Who can say if what she saw was the man that wasnt there or the woman beneath. She speaks the words husband stay and the echo of them hangs in the air like smoke. Even Orsino who thought himself immune to such confusion finds his heart speaking in strange tongues. Boy thou hast said to me a thousand times. As if repetition could make the lie more true.

These people move through their world like sleepwalkers. Each one carrying some secret flame. Some hidden truth they dare not name. The disguise becomes a mirror and in it they see what they fear to see. What they hope to see. What was there all along.

When the truth finally comes it comes like rain after drought. Washing away the masks. The pretense. Olivia finds her heart can shift like quicksilver from Cesario to Sebastian. As if love were nothing but a trick of light. A sister you are she, she says to Viola. As if family could be claimed as easily as changing clothes. But blood knows blood and perhaps in the end that's all that matters.

In this world of shadows and mirrors perhaps there are no true faces. Only the ones we choose to wear and the ones we're born with and sometimes you cant tell one from the other. The deception that saves can also destroy and in the end each must choose which truth to embrace and which to let slip away into the darkness like a dream half-remembered.

He'd seen it in the books. German rule and what it brung. The Herero dead and the Nama too and the bones bleached white in that hard African sun. But you couldn't say it was all one thing or another. Nothing ever was.

In the east they'd found them reading. Africans with books in their hands like they'd been born to it. The British come in 1919 and there they were. In Kamerun too they'd done some good if you could call it that. If you could call any of it good.

But South West Africa was different. A hard land. Cruel. Like it had been born mean and stayed that way. No government schools there. Just missionaries working with what little they had which wasnt much. White children got their learning though. Got it good and proper with government money behind it. These things lasted. After the Germans were gone most blacks still couldn't read nor write nor cipher. Couldn't do none of it.

He studied the old papers. German mostly. Yellowed and crisp like dead leaves. Early writings just telling how things was. Later ones in English trying to make sense of it all. Compare this place to that place. Why things was different here than there. Cohen wrote on it. Said it was the settlers made it what it was.

The weather wasn't so bad in South West Africa. Not good neither but a man could live there if he had to. By 1913 fifteen thousand whites had come. More than anywhere else in German Africa. East Africa only had five thousand and some. Like they knew something. Like they could smell what was coming.

The land stretched out before him raw and empty. Desert mostly. The kind of place where a man's dreams die slow and hard. Where the past aint never really past and the future's just more of the same. Where education was just another way of saying who was gonna make it and who wasn't. Who was gonna live and who was gonna die.

They stood there, the two nations, like ancient beasts eyeing each other across a divide of dust and blood. Fifty-seven years they watched and waited, from 1836 to 1893, marking time in the language of war and bitter memory. The war came in '46, when American boots ground Mexican earth beneath them and claimed Texas and the Southwest territories like a wolf claims the throat of its prey.

The hatred ran deep as a river cut through stone. Catholic and Protestant, Spanish and English blood, each carrying the old world's poison in their veins. The border between them was a wound that wouldn't heal, leaking bandits and desperados like pus from an infection. Seventeen times they clashed, counting the moments between like a man counts the seconds before a hanging.

The border towns lay scattered like broken teeth along a jawline of desert. Raiders crossed back and forth, ghosts in the scorched earth carrying death in their saddlebags. Military men from both sides walked the line with iron in their hands and steel in their eyes, but the blood kept flowing like water in a dry creek after rain.

The rivalry was born in difference, in the way men look at God through different windows and see different shapes in the darkness. Americans feared the Catholic cross like they later feared the hammer and sickle, their Protestant hearts hardened against the old Spanish ways. These fears were carried across oceans in the holds of ships, passed down like dark heirlooms from England and Spain.

But time changes all things. Mexico grew dependent on American gold like a plant bends toward the sun. American eyes turned from land to money, from conquest to commerce. The old hatred didn't die but transformed, became something else, something that could be counted in ledger books instead of bodies.

They were like all border nations, these two. Locked together in a dance of blood and suspicion, until the music changed and they found new steps to follow. Only Mexico and Cuba, they said, only these caused such trouble in American minds, such persistent shadows in American dreams. The others, those further south, they kept their distance and their peace, watching from afar as the great beasts circled each other in their ancient ritual of rivalry and need.

Fifteen years back the sickness come. Never knew such a thing existed till it laid me flat. Was workin as a nurse then. Chose that path cause I needed something solid and sure, something I never had growing up. They kept telling me people would always need tending to, always get sick. So I turned away from what I wanted - to be writing about science and such - and took up nursing instead.

There I was. Forty-six years lived and alone. No money stored away and couldn't work no more. Still can't. After fifteen years living off government checks ain't got nothing to call mine anymore. Each day's a battle against the void, eating away at what little security remained. Nothing certain now except one truth that stands like bedrock: couldn't have made it without my people - family and them few friends that stuck. When disaster comes it strips you bare of any notion of strength you thought you had.

Fact is there'll always be trouble coming. Big or small, don't matter how ready you think you are. Some things just too vast to weather alone. Like them pioneers crossing the mountains west. Wasn't no rugged individual made it alone - was people helping people, sharing what little they had. Respect and mercy, that's what got them through.

These days folks talk about standing alone, being independent. But that ain't the truth of it. This country wasn't built on going it alone. Was built on people knowing their neighbors, helping when help was needed.

Got my emergency supplies like anyone should. Water tablets and plastic sheeting. Duct tape for the windows case something biological comes. Flashlights and batteries and matches that'll light in the rain. Canned goods too. If you got land, work it. Put up food for winter. Get yourself a wood stove if you ain't living in them stacked-up boxes in town.

But while you're doing all that surviving, know your people. Know your neighbors. Cause when the real darkness comes, ain't no one makes it alone.

He was born in the old world, a prince they say, five hundred years before the carpenter. They would call him Buddha. He walked away from his palace and his wealth and found something else entirely. Found enlightenment they called it. His words spread like wildfire through the east and became something else. Something called Buddhism. The Theravada they named it. Pure. Orthodox. Ancient.

Twenty five hundred years gone now. Time changes all things. Even the words of gods. You can see it in Sri Lanka where they cut the waters each year like some ritual older than memory. Monks in their robes. Common folk too. Buddha never spoke of such things but there it is all the same. The changes run deeper than ceremony. Run down into the bones of belief itself. The sangha brotherhood and the folk who follow them have watched their teachings shift like sand in wind. Some changes came from within their walls some from without. Some meant harm. Some meant nothing at all.

Words mean things here. Internal is what comes from their own. External what comes from strangers. Hostile means to harm. To break. To unmake what Buddha built. Benign means no harm intended though harm might come all the same. These words will walk with us through this tale.

First you must know what lies at the heart. They seek refuge in three things. Buddha. Dhamma. Sangha. The Dhamma lives in three baskets of ancient text. Suttas that tell the tales. Vinaya that makes the rules. Abhidhamma that speaks of what lies beyond the veil of flesh. They speak of Anatta - that no soul exists. Of Dukkha - that life is suffering. Of Anicca - that nothing lasts. Only by knowing these truths can one break free of the wheel. The endless cycle of death and birth they call Sansara. When it breaks so too breaks desire and hatred and the fog of delusion that clouds mens minds.

The Vinaya speaks of how to live. Five rules for common folk. Dont kill. Dont lie. Dont steal. Keep your loins in check. Stay clear of drink and smoke that clouds the mind. Monks have more chains to wear. But at the heart of it all lie four noble truths. First that life is suffering. Second that wanting makes us suffer. Third that suffering can end.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
In order for the brain to process information, it must first be stored. There are multiple types of memory, including sensory, working, and long-term. First, information is encoded. There are types of encoding specific to each type of sensory stimuli. For example, verbal input can be encoded structurally, referring to what the printed word looks like, phonemically, referring to what the word sounds like, or semantically, referring to what the word means. Once information is stored, it must be maintained. Some animal studies suggest that working memory, which stores information for roughly 20 seconds, is maintained by an electrical signal looping through a particular series of neurons for a short period of time. Information in long-term memory is hypothesized to be maintained in the structure of certain types of proteins.
There are numerous models of how the knowledge is organized in the brain, some based on the way human subjects retrieve memories, others based on computer science, and others based on neurophysiology. The semantic network model states that there are nodes representing concepts, and that the nodes are linked based on their relatedness. For example, in a semantic network, “chair” might be linked to “table,” which can be linked to “wooden,” and so forth.

In 2007, the United States of America fell into a crushing financial crisis. Unemployment increased, the housing market crashed, and many of America’s largest and most important corportations were left in ruin. This recession persists today, so we must ask the question: how did this crisis occur, and how can we stop it? In short, the financial crisis was created by selfish and naïve political decision-making that pressured banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into an already immature and unsufficient financial infrastructure. Meanwhile, Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC) were pressured to underwite and repackage these mortgages into CDO’s and CDS’. When borrowers defaulted on these loans, the banks were short on capital reserve and transferred this chaos onto the repacked mortgages that they had sold, and on to the rest of the economy.
	The financial crisis had its roots in 1999 of the Clinton era, as the President was aiming for a second term in office. He sought to extend his presidential tenure by augmenting his popularity. To accomplish this the Clinton administration relaxed lending restrictions, which helped to set the grim stage for the sub-prime crisis seven years later.  Steven Holmes of the New York Times reported in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” Holmes would go on to correctly foresee the consequences of these actions: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As detailed in the introduction, and as Holmes foresaw, ill-advised lending would certainly lead to the meltdown of the economy.
	Many factors combined to throw the economy into tailspin, one of which was the new and complex structure of mortgages. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations (CDO’s) were all used extensively in the years leading up to the crisis, and only served to intertwine more sectors of the economy into the housing market. This led to U.S. households, and financial markets in general, to overleverage themselves in the housing market, leaving them extremely vulnerable to even small changes in price. 
	Indeed, the housing bubble burst, and the financial institutions that had bought these mortgage-backed securities were spited. The top five U.S. investment banks all together reported $4.1 trillion dollars of mortgage debts in 2007, which accounted for about 30% of the USA’s GDP. In the end, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch were sold exceptionally cheap, Lehman Brothers was dismantled, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to become commercial banks subjected to intense regulation. Fannie and Freddie were $5 trillion in mortgage debt, and were placed under government control in September 2008.

Ah, exposition.  That place in your story where you stretch your little writer's wings and take flight, astounding one and all with your magnetic, nay magical prose.  Or the part where your readers fall asleep and/or hit the "Back" button while cursing your name.  Dr. Merlin has been known to shout at her monitor when she finds herself in the middle of Too Much Information, and not even in the fun way.

Exposition is not your friend.

My gentle readers already know the basic writing tip, "Show, don't tell," but Dr. Merlin still stumbles into long passages of text where nothing happens, or worse, too much.  Exposition is the little devil sitting on your shoulder that says to get the history out of the way to get to the good parts (not to be confused with the devil sitting on the other shoulder urging the author to tell her audience every single detail of the childhoods of each character).

Exposition means telling the audience what happened, typically in simple prose.  In film, the exposition happens when one character tells another a core-dump of information ala "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner."  In fiction, the author's doing the telling.

An example is in order.  As you are reading a story, you are told that the heroine met her beloved at such a place and time, that they were married in a gala fashion, and that her husband was murdered in front of her eyes.  You would not expect this entire sequence to take two pages, during which time both he and she only get two lines of dialogue each.  You would expect the author to spend some time on the husband's character, evidencing by his speech and manner how deeply he loves his wife, and you would equally expect the heroine to show through big and small ways how much his presence in her life changed and enriched her (especially if the story were to tell you flat out later that this was the case).  A proper introduction to the husband's character would allow you to become emotionally involved with his fate and would give you insight into the heroine's character: what she saw in him, how deep their bond was, clues about her thoughts and beliefs and dreams as reflected through the prism of his eyes, and so on.  You would mourn his death with her, and so grow more connected to the heroine herself.

In short, you would expect meat on the simple bone of the storyline: "They met, they married, he died."

As a writer, you need to provide that meat.  (*looks at metaphor, sighs, plunges onward*)  Sometimes it is tempting to rush past certain things.  Perhaps you're introducing a new character and you know he used to be in the Air Force, and he's the night manager of a gas station now, and he was married twice, no kids, likes to go fishing on the weekends, secretly dreams of owning the gas station someday and had Eggs Benedict for breakfast.

I watched two newscast’s from Columbus, Ohio. The first one that was “live” was NBC 4 this morning (August 13, 2011). The lead story was about a man in Ashley, Ohio who had stabbed his wife, it did not state her name however his name was Shad Hostettler. They showed his mug shot and he looked like pure evil. They devoted only about two minutes to this story as it was developing. The only details they provide he had stabbed her multiple times and had been arrested. I think they spent an appropriate amount of time on this story. 
	The second story was about an early morning shooting of Travis Buyers, 18. He was shot in the Sharon Woods area and had been critically injured; there had been no arrests made at the time or any suspects. The SWAT Team was investigating the crime. This story seemed to be short, and I believe that might have been due to the fact this was a “black” man or a black neighborhood. I noticed (and have for years) that minorities are glossed over when they are a victim of a crime. If say a “white” child or adult is kidnapped or missing or a victim of a crime the media goes nuts; but if a minority person it’s lucky if it is even mentioned. 
	The next story was about the gunshot hole that had been found in the Med-Flight helicopter. Details were given about where they thought the incident happened. It had been determined that it was a .22 caliber bullet from a rifle that had hit the helicopter. Crime-Stoppers are offering a five-thousand dollar reward for tips that lead to the arrest of the shooter. 
	The next story was concerning the rain and thunderstorms predicted for Saturday afternoon. They said the temperatures would remain in the mid to low eighties for the weekend. The length of time was a little short, but they wanted to use it as a “teaser” so that you would stay tuned. 
	They also ran with a story about a robbery of a Clime Road UDF in Columbus. They said it was dark-skinned black man who robbed the store he was wearing a hoodie sweatshirt. They said he was about six-foot tall and weighed about one hundred and fifty pounds. I thought they devoted an unusual about of time emphasizing he was black and how dark he was. 
	Another story was about a Rene Rodriguez who was a convicted Texas Drug-Kingpin. He had been convicted of conspiring to distribute marijuana in large amounts to Ohio from Texas. One curious thing I noted, was instead of saying he was sentenced to twenty-five years in prison they said “300” months. I am not sure what the angle was there, whether they thought that sounded more harsh or what. They also mentioned he was a Hispanic man, I don’t believe that was really germane to the story.

An ETF, or exchange traded fund, is a security that is designed to track an index, a commodity or a basket of assets like an index fund, but is more flexible and trades like a stock on an exchange.  An ETF gives you the diversification of an index fund and the benefits of single stock ownership like the ability to sell short, buy on margin and purchase as few as a one share in any transaction.  Though these benefits are extremely attractive, the expense ratios of ETFs are far lower than those of the average mutual fund.  Unfortunately, there are some down sides, such as the need to pay a commission on any trade involving ETFs, just as you would pay on a stock order.  Another benefit of ETFs is the wide variety of funds available.  Though these benefits are clearly stated, it is always a good exercise for the savvy financial investor to evaluate whether stated benefits, like diversification, do indeed exist, and the extent to which they exist.  For the purposes of this effort, we will be examining the ETF IHF and comparing it against the top 10 holdings that comprise the ETF to determine whether the benefits of a owning a single ETF come close to the benefits of owning a diversified portfolio of the ten stocks and also whether or not there are better configurations of the same stocks that would provide a more optimal sharp ratio or return.
	In order to evaluate the ETF, it would become rather unwieldy to include every holding, therefore we have decided to include only the top ten holdings accounting for 63.58% of all the assets in the ETF.  Below are the top 10 holdings and the percentage of total assets.

	In order to gain an estimation of how well these ten stocks represent the ETF IHF as a whole, we can use the current % of assets, normalized to 100%, to  calculate the contributions of each stock to a portfolioâ€™s Beta and Return if the portfolio was made up entirely of these 10 stocks in the proportion that the ETF has established through their holdings.  The calculations of Beta and return are included in the below chart.

From the above chart it is evident that the return of a portfolio containing only the top 10 holdings is 6.11% higher than the ETF, a 16% increase in returns.  It is also evident that the Beta of the top ten holdings is .12 lower than the ETF as a whole.  From the results completed thus far, it seems that a portfolio of just the top 10 holdings could provide a higher return with a lower beta.  However, there is a possibility that the means of these two portfolios may not be statistically different from each other.
	In order to evaluate whether or not these portfolios are statistically different, the standard deviation of each of the top 10 stocks is determined and normalized to 100% in order to compare their accumulated standard deviation to that of the ETF IHF.

Referring back to Figure 17, there was a precipitous drop in commuter log submissions in the third month of the project. That was a bit disheartening, and it is hard to say why that might have happened. With the onset of winter at a New England campus, there is clearly a drop in people commuting either by bicycle or by foot, which may account for some portion of the decline. December also marks the end of the fall semester when everyone is very busy finishing schoolwork, processing grades, and so forth.
