But there was something else. Something closer. The German writers had gotten into Poe's blood like a fever. Their words moved through him like dark water through deep caves.

There was Goethe. His Faust stood like a monument, carved in two great pieces across the years - first in 1808 and again in 1832 when death finally took him. Within those pages lay "The King of Thulé" like a dark jewel. It told of a king whose queen had passed beyond the veil, leaving him nothing but a goblet and his grief. He drank deep from both until neither could sustain him. When the end came he gave away his kingdom like a man shrugging off a heavy coat, keeping only that cup, that last token of love. Then he walked out onto the cliffs above the sea, black water moving below. The goblet caught the light one final time before he cast it into the depths. Then he closed his eyes and followed it into darkness.

The shade of that tale fell across Poe's "Dream-Land" like an evening shadow. He wrote of Thule twice, bookending his verses with that ancient word as though to mark the borders of that desolate realm. His speaker wandered landscapes stripped of color, haunted by the ghosts of dead companions, moving through a world as empty as the one Goethe's king had left behind.

The connection ran deeper than chance. Poe knew Goethe's work - how could he not? It moved through the literary world like blood through veins. When they spoke of Tennyson, Poe would nod, knowing the threads that bound them all together across the dark waters of influence and time. The reproductions of Goethe's work spread like ripples in still water, touching everything. Even Grattan had shaped Faust anew in 1842, barely a year before Poe set down "The Pit and the Pendulum" with its own whispered mention of ultima Thule.

They'd tell stories later about that day at D&D Markets. About the applesauce that lay there like some pale viscous blood upon the floor and how Martin sat in his office eating while fate worked its slow arithmetic in the aisles beyond. The spill had come at five. Wayne had seen it first. Told Martin who sat there behind his desk with his dinner laid out before him like some pagan offering to darker gods. Didn't have time for customer complaints he'd said. His voice flat and dead as winter.

Fifteen minutes passed and Haddigan came. She too bore witness to the creeping danger in aisle four but Martin would not be moved. He sat immobile as stone while time crept past like a thief in the night. Half past five Palmer came. She never saw what took her feet from under her. Never saw the applesauce gleaming dull and treacherous in the fluorescent light. Her back broke bad and she fell into darkness deeper than any night.

The law spoke of malice and oppression and fraud. Spoke of despicable acts committed with willful disregard. Six souls had fallen in those aisles that year alone. Six victims to negligence and indifference cold as the tile floor itself. The judges knew such things. Had seen them written in blood and broken bones across the years. Taylor's case spoke of dangerous consequences known but not heeded. Of willful failure to act when action might have saved.

Martin knew. He knew and still he sat. Still he ate while danger waited patient as a rattler in the aisles. The law would not look kindly on such things. Would not shield him from the punishment such calculated indifference called forth. Palmer's claim would stand. The courts would hear her tale of woe and pain. Of a manager who chose his dinner over duty. Who let peril stalk his store while he supped in safety.

The law was clear as morning. Clear as the applesauce that lay there waiting. Punitive damages would come like judgment day. No summary dismissal would save them now. The facts lay bare as bones and twice as damning. They would pay in coin and conscience both.

The wanting had come early. Like a shadow that follows but never catches up. Started when she was fourteen and lingered still at seventeen, a ghost of need that wouldnt rest. Not a thing she needed no. A someone. But the boys that came didnt matter none. They'd circle like crows round a dying thing, awkward in their courtship, but she felt nothing for them. Nothing at all. She'd lay awake studying the ceiling, questioning what darkness lived inside her that made her this way. Years passed like that. No answers came.

The house was quiet mostly. Her folks were peaceful folk who rarely raised their voices, save when their daughter's wild spirit crashed against their stillness like waves on stone. She was their opposite, full of life and light that drew others to her like moths to flame. Good hearted too. Kind.

But this day wasnt quiet. No. This day carried something else. She wandered room to room searching for something she couldn't name when her mother's scream cut through the silence like broken glass. Kitchen. She ran. Found her mother laid out on the tile floor, face twisted in pain, breath coming short and sharp.

Mama what's wrong? She knelt beside her mother who could barely speak through the hurt. Hospital, her mother managed. Just take me there.

The girl gathered her mother up, thankful for the strength in her arms from all them classes she'd taken. Carried her to the car and laid her in the back like something precious and broken. Drove fast through streets gone colorless with worry.

The hospital reeked of death and cleaning fluid but she noticed none of it. Just carried her mother through them sliding doors calling for help until white-coated figures appeared like ghosts from the fluorescent haze. They took her mother away on a wheeled bed and left the girl alone with her fear.

Later they told her. Her mother had been reaching for some old vase, balanced on a stepstool like a bird on a wire. Then gravity remembered her and brought her down hard to the unforgiving earth.

They watched them dying year by year. Hearts giving out like old clockwork, blood vessels clogged and useless. The nurses knew. They'd seen it before and they'd see it again. Seventy four thousand of them watching and waiting and marking their charts with what they ate and what they didn't. Mediterranean style they called it. Plants and fish and oils pressed from ancient trees. No meat to speak of. Like them old desert people used to eat before the world went wrong.

The women they studied weren't sick yet. Not with the sugar disease nor the heart troubles. Thirty eight to sixty three years old they was. Every few years they'd write down what passed their lips. Everything catalogued like a church inventory. Two decades of eating and dying. Some quit the study but most stayed on. Faithful as converts to some old religion.

The doctors checked every death. Every seized-up heart, every blood vessel burst in the brain. They'd look at papers and records and death certificates like archaeological artifacts. Sometimes there weren't no records to speak of. They called them probable cases and counted them anyway. Seventeen percent of the strokes. Twenty four percent of the heart attacks that didn't kill.

They kept track of everything. Weight and smoking and pills they took. Whether their monthly blood still came or if it had stopped. Whether they moved their bodies or just sat still. Like bookkeepers tallying up the accounts of lives lived and lost.

They used numbers to wash away the noise. Averaged everything together like mixing paint. Tried to account for things that might lead them astray. Age and smoking and all them other habits that kill.

After twenty years they had their answer written in blood and death. Two thousand heart attacks. Near eighteen hundred strokes. Over a thousand dead from their hearts or their heads giving out. But them that ate like them old Mediterranean people, they lived longer. Twenty nine percent longer than them that didn't. Like some old testament prophecy come true in hospital corridors and nursing stations. Eat of these foods and live. Eat of the others and die.

The sign said Hitler lives in Burma and the girl held it there above her head in the gray morning light. The cardboard bent and weathered like something pulled from an ancient tomb. Standing alone on that corner like a prophet of old. The country they called Burma once and Myanmar now lay far across waters dark and deep where men in uniforms ruled with iron and blood since before most could remember. The military junta they called them. Words that meant nothing to the dead.

In the year two thousand and seven the monks rose up. Orange robed like flames against the concrete and steel of the cities. The Saffron Revolution they named it but revolutions aint got much to do with spices and this one was no different. At first the government let them march. Let them gather. Then the violence came as it always does. Ancient monasteries ransacked and burning. Journalists rounded up or shot dead in the streets. One Japanese man named Nagai caught it there on the concrete while his camera kept rolling til the end.

They said thirteen dead but a colonel who fled told different stories. Bodies stacked like cordwood in the thousands. The government denied it as governments do. Ancient as time itself this need to rule. To stamp out the light wherever it shows. Roman emperors who called themselves gods. Japanese kings descended from heaven itself. Our own president taking counsel from prophets and madmen every seventh day.

In China they gunned down students in the streets of Tiananmen. The numbers changed depending on who did the counting but the dead stayed dead all the same. In Rwanda the Hutus killed their Tutsi neighbors with machetes and clubs til the streets ran red. And before all that there was Hitler. The girl with the sign knew. Knew how these things went. How they always went. Evil didnt die. It just moved on down the road looking for new places to root.

The old jazzman's shadow stretched long across them decades like some dark thing that wouldnt die. Piano keys worn smooth by time and the endless nights. He didnt play much but when he did it was like rainwater falling soft on tin. His real power lay in knowing the souls of them that played for him. Each one carrying their own particular sound like a birthmark or a scar. He wrote the music but it wasnt just notes on paper. It was blood and breath.

The book men talk about something called Creole Love Call like it was just another piece of music but it wasnt. Voice rising up out of nowhere like some lost spirit crying in the dark. No words. No words needed. Just pure sound floating above them reeds like smoke. Blues wrapped around blues wrapped around blues six times over.

First the voice comes pure as morning then turns rough like somebody dragged it through gravel. Then that trumpet crying through the mute like it knows something about suffering. Clarinet floating high and lonesome while the piano whispers underneath. Then the whole band takes up the cry, brass and reeds calling back and forth like wolves in the night. Fifth time through everything rises up fierce and wild, them reeds screaming high while brass and rhythm punch holes in the dark below. Last time voice comes back growling like some creature that aint human no more. At the end just a run of notes and that trombone laughing bitter and wrong.

Year later he done Hot and Bothered. Miley on trumpet and Cox singing sounds that wasnt words, just pure music. Like they was having some kind of conversation that normal folks couldnt understand. Then that piece about swing, Nanton making that trombone talk like it had a human tongue. Playing sounds that wasnt never meant to come from brass and metal.

That was his gift. Taking human sounds and making them mechanical. Taking machine sounds and making them human. Mixing them all up till you couldnt tell which was which no more. Like some kind of dark alchemy. Like he knew something about music that wasnt in no books nowhere.

He sat there studying the shells. Ancient things. Spiraling through time and space like some cosmic dance frozen in calcium. The old man Thompson had said it back in 1917 that no man could speak the language of these forms in numbers and equations and even now a hundred years hence they still could not. Not really.

The shells lay before him on the wooden table. Prunum specimens collected from waters he'd never see. Each one a record of life and death and the slow accretion of being. Mathematical models could tell you something of their growing but not everything. Never everything. They'd X-rayed them, fed numbers into machines called CerioShell that spat out predictions of what could be and what couldn't. As if the world needed telling.

The shell was a house built by its tenant, spiral upon spiral like the chambers of some infinite heart. Whorls, they called them. Each one marking time like rings in a tree, each one pressed against an axis running through the center that men had named columella though God knows what the creature called it. If it called it anything at all. The last chamber always the largest, like the final breath of a dying thing. They had names for every part. Apex and base and aperture. Words to cage the mystery but never quite holding it.

You could turn them this way and that. View them from above or below or straight on but they kept their secrets. Counting the whorls was like counting the years of the dead. Draw a line and start where the first suture begins, marking quarter turns like the phases of some calcium moon.

The path of growth could be tracked. Numbers assigned to the spacing and the width and the height as if that could capture the essence of the thing. As if mathematics could explain the why of it all. But the numbers were just shadows on the cave wall, telling nothing of the thing itself. Of what drove it to build in curves and spirals, to leave these empty houses scattered on the shores of time.

He touched one shell with a finger. Smooth and cold. Wondering what compulsion had driven its maker through the dark waters, adding layer upon layer in the blind faith that this was what it must do. This was its purpose. This was its being. Mathematical models could predict the possible but never the necessary. Never the why of it all.

He studied the numbers before him, cold figures that spoke of death in the far reaches of those islands. Ten years and nothing changed. Children dying same as they always had. Mothers too. The government men had their goals written in fine ink on clean paper but the truth was darker, more brutal than their neat columns could tell.

In the cities now you might find someone who knew the way of birth. Seventy-two out of hundred they said. But these weren't doctors with their clean hands and sharp tools. Just women who'd seen enough blood to know its ways. When the bleeding started they had nothing but old ways and prayers. He'd seen it. The dark blood flowing like river water in the night.

The children still died of the flux, their small bodies wracked with it. Less help now than before. The numbers told that truth plain enough. In the towns where the roads were paved you might find a doctor to cut the baby free. Seven in hundred. But in the places where the dirt was still dirt and men lived close to the bone it was two. Just two. The math was simple as a knife.

Rich folk got their care. Poor folk died. Twenty-seven percent difference they called it. He called it blood money. Called it the price of being born wrong.

They talked about programs now. Special ways to fix special problems. But he knew better. Knew you couldn't patch a rotting house board by board. The whole thing needed tearing down, building new from foundation up. They'd tried it before with the plague that took men's blood. Threw money at it like water on a fire. But the fire just moved elsewhere, burned through the family planning houses instead. That's how money worked. Like water finding the low ground.

The papers piled up on desks. Forms in triplicate. Programs layered on programs like old paint, each one hiding the rot beneath. But the children still died. The mothers still bled. And the numbers stayed cold as stones.

The music they called Popular had grown and spread like some dark vine across the century past, spawning genres uncountable, each one birthing more in its wake. They had names for them all. Rap and rock and country and jazz and folk but these were just words men had given to something that defied naming. And from these came others still, subspecies breeding in the dark corners of sound until they became something else entirely.

Among these bastard children was one they called Heavy Metal. It came forth some forty years ago and grew like something feral, something that refused to be contained. It spoke in tongues of darkness and carried within it emotions raw and terrible as birth. Men saw in it something malleable, something that could be shaped and reformed endless times, and so they did.

Now the thing has grown so vast and strange that none can say what it truly is anymore. It feeds on other sounds, other genres, consuming them and making them its own. To understand this thing you must go back to its beginning, to the dark soil from which it grew. For this aint no mere category of sound. This is something that moves through the world like a fever through the blood.

The darkness lies at its core like a black seed. Everything about it demands more. More thunder in the bass, more volume to shatter eardrums, more violence in its execution. The players themselves became technicians of sound, masters of their craft in ways the old musicians never were. And always there were the drugs, flowing through the veins of the seventies like poison, making men create sounds that weren't of this earth. They used these chemicals like shamans use their herbs, to touch something beyond the veil of reality.

It carried within it something visceral, something that hadn't existed in the popular sounds that came before. It reached back to the dark romanticism of another age, pulling forth themes of death and decay and loss. Even the Beatles, those prophets of love and light, found themselves drawn to its power. They wrote Helter Skelter like men possessed, trying to outdo the Stones in their descent into the maelstrom. That song stands now like a marker, a sign pointing toward the darkness to come.

In the time before the dreamers took to their canvases with their wild visions, there was Rousseau. He who held his brushes like ancient tools of some forgotten ceremony. The Dream they called it, this thing he made in 1910, this fever vision of woman and jungle and night. She lay there midst the dark fronds and violet blooms, pale as bone china in the spectral light, while all round her the jungle breathed and watched with golden eyes.

He'd come to painting late, had Rousseau. No schooling in the arts save what the world had writ upon his heart. Born to a tinsmith in Laval where the gray streets wound down to the river and the sounds of hammering rang out across the morning fog. For forty years he collected tolls, counted coins, watched faces pass. They called him douanier though that wasnt right. Gabelou was what he was. A counter of small coins. A keeper of minor gates.

Grief walked with him like a shadow. Eight children born dead or dying. His wife Clémence taken too, leaving him with only Julia, this one daughter like a single candle burning in a vast and darkened room. And so he turned to paint and canvas like a man turns to prayer, seeking something that might fill the emptiness.

He worked in silence while around him others rose to fame. Matisse with his wild colors burning holes in canvas. But Rousseau, he painted slow and careful like a man trying to remember something seen in dreams. Some said he wanted only to be accepted, to make the kind of paintings that would open doors. But in his heart he knew. The jungle waited. The dreams came calling. And he answered them with brush and paint, making worlds that never were but somehow always had been.

The critics laughed. The galleries turned away. But still he painted on, each stroke a defiance, each canvas a door opened onto somewhere else. Somewhere in the dark beyond the firelight where the dreams still walked upright and spoke in tongues of flame and shadow.

He sat there thinking on them that came before, them great minds what spoke of truth and beauty being bound together like twins in the womb. Something in that notion rang true deep down in the marrow of things. Old Keats had wrote it plain as day in his poem bout that old urn, said beauty and truth was one and the same and that was all any man needed knowing in this world. Most things a man learns comes from books or hard living but these things, the knowing of what's right and what's beautiful, they come to a man different. Like they was already there waiting to be found.

He remembered studying them paintings in museums, folk talking bout foreground and background and such, trying to pin down why something like that Mona Lisa woman spoke to the soul. But words failed. Always failed. People'd look at some painting or read some book that moved em and they'd say there was just something about it before they started in with their fancy talk. Truth was you couldn't never capture it complete. That O'Connor woman knew it, said some things could only be told in stories cause regular words wouldn't do.

The boy looked up at him. What are you thinking about Papa?

About truth and beauty son. About how they're like ghosts you can feel but cant never quite catch hold of.

Like God?

Maybe so. Maybe just so.

He thought on how both goodness and beauty worked on a man's soul in ways that couldn't be spoke proper. Like they was both reaching down from some higher place, touching something deep inside that was beyond telling. Them books he'd read talked about noumenal things, things that could be felt but not explained. That's what it was like. The knowing of right from wrong and the knowing of beauty, they was kin somehow. Connected in that deep place where words don't go.

Especially in them stories folk wrote. McKean had it right when he said stories was different from other arts cause they carried the weight of living in em. Values and such. The choosing between right and wrong. Just like real life only distilled down somehow. Pure. Like truth and beauty was just different words for the same thing after all.

The land stretches vast and cold from the teeth of the alps down to where the Baltic meets the shore at Kiel, a place where men speak in low voices and the wind carries salt. This is Germany. The same blood runs through the veins of those who dwell by the Rhine at Köln as those who wake in Dresden where the Elbe cuts through stone like an ancient knife. The people carry something in them older than memory. Something that came before.

They called it Germania once. The old ones did. The name itself is lost to time like footprints in ash, disputed by learned men who speak in whispers through dusty tomes. Tacitus, dead these thousand years, wrote of the Tungrians who crossed the Rhine with blood in their eyes and war in their hearts. Caesar too spoke of them. Called them Germanus in his writings of the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls like dogs but could not tame those who dwelt beyond the river. He took the word from the Gauls themselves, though what it meant none now living can say. Some claim it spoke of neighbors. Others say it named the spears they carried, dark instruments of death called ger, or maybe it came from garim, an old Irish word for shouting, for these were a people who made the very air tremble with their voices.

Tacitus wrote more. In 98 he put down words about these people, claiming they were pure as winter snow, unmixed with the blood of others. Who would come here, he asked, to this wild country with its bitter sky and darker ways? Who indeed would leave warm southern lands for this place unless it was already branded on their soul?

The Romans would not. They sent their legions north for plunder and glory but always they returned south like birds in autumn, back to their marble halls and heated baths. The Germanic tribes lived on the edge of this empire of stone and law, trading what the land gave them and sometimes their own blood, serving in the ranks of armies not their own. They were there in the middle of that first century, watching, waiting, their destiny as yet unwritten in the book of days.

The play stretches out before us like some vast tapestry of deception, each thread woven through with lies that must someday unravel or else consume the weaver whole. They'd called it Twelfth Night though it mightve been called anything. A story of masks and faces beneath masks and the terrible price of wearing either too long.

The girl Viola comes to strange shores. Comes walking out of the sea like some halfdrowned thing. She takes a mans clothes and a mans name as if such things could be borrowed like coins. Protection she called it. As if cloth and leather could ward off the worlds malice. But the disguise that saves can also damn and she found herself cut off from the women who mightve been sisters to her. Cast adrift in a wilderness of her own making.

The noble Olivia sees this false man Cesario and something burns in her that maybe shouldnt burn. Who can say if what she saw was the man that wasnt there or the woman beneath. She speaks the words husband stay and the echo of them hangs in the air like smoke. Even Orsino who thought himself immune to such confusion finds his heart speaking in strange tongues. Boy thou hast said to me a thousand times. As if repetition could make the lie more true.

These people move through their world like sleepwalkers. Each one carrying some secret flame. Some hidden truth they dare not name. The disguise becomes a mirror and in it they see what they fear to see. What they hope to see. What was there all along.

When the truth finally comes it comes like rain after drought. Washing away the masks. The pretense. Olivia finds her heart can shift like quicksilver from Cesario to Sebastian. As if love were nothing but a trick of light. A sister you are she, she says to Viola. As if family could be claimed as easily as changing clothes. But blood knows blood and perhaps in the end that's all that matters.

In this world of shadows and mirrors perhaps there are no true faces. Only the ones we choose to wear and the ones we're born with and sometimes you cant tell one from the other. The deception that saves can also destroy and in the end each must choose which truth to embrace and which to let slip away into the darkness like a dream half-remembered.

He'd seen it in the books. German rule and what it brung. The Herero dead and the Nama too and the bones bleached white in that hard African sun. But you couldn't say it was all one thing or another. Nothing ever was.

In the east they'd found them reading. Africans with books in their hands like they'd been born to it. The British come in 1919 and there they were. In Kamerun too they'd done some good if you could call it that. If you could call any of it good.

But South West Africa was different. A hard land. Cruel. Like it had been born mean and stayed that way. No government schools there. Just missionaries working with what little they had which wasnt much. White children got their learning though. Got it good and proper with government money behind it. These things lasted. After the Germans were gone most blacks still couldn't read nor write nor cipher. Couldn't do none of it.

He studied the old papers. German mostly. Yellowed and crisp like dead leaves. Early writings just telling how things was. Later ones in English trying to make sense of it all. Compare this place to that place. Why things was different here than there. Cohen wrote on it. Said it was the settlers made it what it was.

The weather wasn't so bad in South West Africa. Not good neither but a man could live there if he had to. By 1913 fifteen thousand whites had come. More than anywhere else in German Africa. East Africa only had five thousand and some. Like they knew something. Like they could smell what was coming.

The land stretched out before him raw and empty. Desert mostly. The kind of place where a man's dreams die slow and hard. Where the past aint never really past and the future's just more of the same. Where education was just another way of saying who was gonna make it and who wasn't. Who was gonna live and who was gonna die.

They stood there, the two nations, like ancient beasts eyeing each other across a divide of dust and blood. Fifty-seven years they watched and waited, from 1836 to 1893, marking time in the language of war and bitter memory. The war came in '46, when American boots ground Mexican earth beneath them and claimed Texas and the Southwest territories like a wolf claims the throat of its prey.

The hatred ran deep as a river cut through stone. Catholic and Protestant, Spanish and English blood, each carrying the old world's poison in their veins. The border between them was a wound that wouldn't heal, leaking bandits and desperados like pus from an infection. Seventeen times they clashed, counting the moments between like a man counts the seconds before a hanging.

The border towns lay scattered like broken teeth along a jawline of desert. Raiders crossed back and forth, ghosts in the scorched earth carrying death in their saddlebags. Military men from both sides walked the line with iron in their hands and steel in their eyes, but the blood kept flowing like water in a dry creek after rain.

The rivalry was born in difference, in the way men look at God through different windows and see different shapes in the darkness. Americans feared the Catholic cross like they later feared the hammer and sickle, their Protestant hearts hardened against the old Spanish ways. These fears were carried across oceans in the holds of ships, passed down like dark heirlooms from England and Spain.

But time changes all things. Mexico grew dependent on American gold like a plant bends toward the sun. American eyes turned from land to money, from conquest to commerce. The old hatred didn't die but transformed, became something else, something that could be counted in ledger books instead of bodies.

They were like all border nations, these two. Locked together in a dance of blood and suspicion, until the music changed and they found new steps to follow. Only Mexico and Cuba, they said, only these caused such trouble in American minds, such persistent shadows in American dreams. The others, those further south, they kept their distance and their peace, watching from afar as the great beasts circled each other in their ancient ritual of rivalry and need.

Fifteen years back the sickness come. Never knew such a thing existed till it laid me flat. Was workin as a nurse then. Chose that path cause I needed something solid and sure, something I never had growing up. They kept telling me people would always need tending to, always get sick. So I turned away from what I wanted - to be writing about science and such - and took up nursing instead.

There I was. Forty-six years lived and alone. No money stored away and couldn't work no more. Still can't. After fifteen years living off government checks ain't got nothing to call mine anymore. Each day's a battle against the void, eating away at what little security remained. Nothing certain now except one truth that stands like bedrock: couldn't have made it without my people - family and them few friends that stuck. When disaster comes it strips you bare of any notion of strength you thought you had.

Fact is there'll always be trouble coming. Big or small, don't matter how ready you think you are. Some things just too vast to weather alone. Like them pioneers crossing the mountains west. Wasn't no rugged individual made it alone - was people helping people, sharing what little they had. Respect and mercy, that's what got them through.

These days folks talk about standing alone, being independent. But that ain't the truth of it. This country wasn't built on going it alone. Was built on people knowing their neighbors, helping when help was needed.

Got my emergency supplies like anyone should. Water tablets and plastic sheeting. Duct tape for the windows case something biological comes. Flashlights and batteries and matches that'll light in the rain. Canned goods too. If you got land, work it. Put up food for winter. Get yourself a wood stove if you ain't living in them stacked-up boxes in town.

But while you're doing all that surviving, know your people. Know your neighbors. Cause when the real darkness comes, ain't no one makes it alone.

He was born in the old world, a prince they say, five hundred years before the carpenter. They would call him Buddha. He walked away from his palace and his wealth and found something else entirely. Found enlightenment they called it. His words spread like wildfire through the east and became something else. Something called Buddhism. The Theravada they named it. Pure. Orthodox. Ancient.

Twenty five hundred years gone now. Time changes all things. Even the words of gods. You can see it in Sri Lanka where they cut the waters each year like some ritual older than memory. Monks in their robes. Common folk too. Buddha never spoke of such things but there it is all the same. The changes run deeper than ceremony. Run down into the bones of belief itself. The sangha brotherhood and the folk who follow them have watched their teachings shift like sand in wind. Some changes came from within their walls some from without. Some meant harm. Some meant nothing at all.

Words mean things here. Internal is what comes from their own. External what comes from strangers. Hostile means to harm. To break. To unmake what Buddha built. Benign means no harm intended though harm might come all the same. These words will walk with us through this tale.

First you must know what lies at the heart. They seek refuge in three things. Buddha. Dhamma. Sangha. The Dhamma lives in three baskets of ancient text. Suttas that tell the tales. Vinaya that makes the rules. Abhidhamma that speaks of what lies beyond the veil of flesh. They speak of Anatta - that no soul exists. Of Dukkha - that life is suffering. Of Anicca - that nothing lasts. Only by knowing these truths can one break free of the wheel. The endless cycle of death and birth they call Sansara. When it breaks so too breaks desire and hatred and the fog of delusion that clouds mens minds.

The Vinaya speaks of how to live. Five rules for common folk. Dont kill. Dont lie. Dont steal. Keep your loins in check. Stay clear of drink and smoke that clouds the mind. Monks have more chains to wear. But at the heart of it all lie four noble truths. First that life is suffering. Second that wanting makes us suffer. Third that suffering can end.
